content.question: The Directive Force…

options.A: is about twice as strong on 60°N/S as on the Equator.
options.B: is zero over the geographical poles.
options.C: is the component of the Earth’s magnetic field which aligns the compass needle.
options.D: equals the vertical component of the Earth’s magnetic field.

key_points: DIRECTIVE FORCE The force tending to cause the directive element of a compass to line up with the reference direction
The horizontal component of earth's magnetic field is known as the "Directive Force", which aligns the compass needle
A freely suspended magnet will align itself with the Earth's magnetic field
learning.explanation: DIRECTIVE FORCE The force tending to cause the directive element of a compass to line up with the reference direction. The horizontal component of earth's magnetic field is known as the "Directive Force", which aligns the compass needle. A freely suspended magnet will align itself with the Earth's magnetic field. The total field (T) is resolved into a horizontal component (H) and a vertical component (Z). HORIZONTAL COMPONENT The horizontal component is the part which is detected by the compass needle in order to determine Magnetic North. A compass is freely suspended in the horizontal plane and the needle will align itself with the Earth's horizontal component (H) of the Earth's magnetic field. The compass is ineffective near the poles. As you approach the poles, the angle between magnetic flux and the horizon becomes vertical – compass ‘dip’ becomes a factor => decrease in horizontal magnetic field, increase in vertical magnetic field. The value of the horizontal component is maximum at the Magnetic Equator, a freely suspended compass needle in the Earth's magnetic field will be horizontal to the Earth - in line with the horizontal component.

content.question:
Which of the following statements about the properties of a simple bar magnet are correct?
1. North or South Poles can exist separately
2. Magnetism is concentrated at the extremities of the bar

key_points: The operating principles of direct reading compasses are based on the fundamentals of magnetism, in particular the interaction between the magnetic field of a suitably suspended magnetic element, and the Earth’s magnetic field
The three principle properties of a simple permanent bar magnet are that: - It attracts other pieces of iron and steel
- Its power of attraction is concentrated at each end of the bar
learning.explanation: The operating principles of direct reading compasses are based on the fundamentals of magnetism, in particular the interaction between the magnetic field of a suitably suspended magnetic element, and the Earth’s magnetic field. The three principle properties of a simple permanent bar magnet are that: - It attracts other pieces of iron and steel. - Its power of attraction is concentrated at each end of the bar. - When suspended to move horizontally, it always comes to rest in an approximately north - south direction. Magnetism is concentrated at a magnet's extremities, called poles. Therefore, statement 2 is correct. Additionally, a freely suspended magnetised rod always aligns itself approximately in a north-south orientation. The end that seeks north is called the north seeking or red pole, and the end that seeks south, is called the south seeking or blue pole. A unit pole cannot exist. If a magnet is cut into two pieces, each piece will have two poles. Therefore, statement 1 is incorrect.

content.question: In a gyromagnetic compass, the flux valve feeds the…

key_points: The gyromagnetic compass is the combination of a simple compass and a gyroscope
The indications of the magnetic compass are stabilized by the gyroscope to reduce the effects of acceleration and turning errors
The main components of a gyromagnetic compass are the flux valve, the heading indicator, the slaving amplifier, the synchronizing motor, and the horizontal gyro
learning.explanation: The gyromagnetic compass is the combination of a simple compass and a gyroscope. The indications of the magnetic compass are stabilized by the gyroscope to reduce the effects of acceleration and turning errors. The main components of a gyromagnetic compass are the flux valve, the heading indicator, the slaving amplifier, the synchronizing motor, and the horizontal gyro. The flux valve senses the Earth’s magnetic field which is compared to the position of the drive shaft connecting the horizontal gyro and the heading indicator. Anytime the gyro has drifted, and its position would differ from the flux valve field, an AC error signal is transmitted to the precession amplifier. Before being converted into a DC signal, the AC signal is first amplified, and phase detected. This signal drives the precession motor that will realign the gyro. The new position is compared again, and the synchronization will continue until the heading indicator is synchronized. The flux valve is usually remotely located in the wingtip or the fin of the aircraft to be free of any magnetic disturbances. An easy way to remember the order of the gyromagnetic compass operation is by using the acronym ‘FEAT’: Flux valve => Error detector => Amplifier => Torque motor

content.question: A pilot wishes to turn left on to a northerly heading with 10° bank at a latitude of 50° North. Using a direct reading compass, in order to achieve this he must stop the turn on an approximate heading of…

key_points: Step 1: Find the direction of the turn – clockwise or anticlockwise? The aircraft turns to the left onto a northerly heading => anticlockwise
Step 2: Use the acronym ‘UNOS’ to find if you will overshoot or undershoot? UN – Undershoot = apparent turn to the North
OS – Overshoot = apparent turn to the South
learning.explanation: Step 1: Find the direction of the turn – clockwise or anticlockwise? The aircraft turns to the left onto a northerly heading => anticlockwise. Step 2: Use the acronym ‘UNOS’ to find if you will overshoot or undershoot? UN – Undershoot = apparent turn to the North. OS – Overshoot = apparent turn to the South. By banking in an anticlockwise direction to 000° (northerly heading), you will need to undershoot by a certain amount if you want to stop your turn exactly at 000°. Step 3: Find the angle by which you will need to overshoot/undershoot by using the following formula (Refer to diagram 1): (Bank angle + Lat) ÷ 2 Remember that the turning error is greatest on a Northerly/Southerly heading. Therefore any time you turn through the North or South the error will be the highest, and any time you turn through West or East the error will be the smallest. Consequently, when your heading is between North and East or South and East, etc. (half-way between two cardinal points) the turning error will be only half as big or twice as big as at these headings. Only in this case, you will use the following formula (Refer to diagram 2) : (Bank angle + Lat) ÷ 4 In this question, the aircraft turns to the left onto heading 000°, so it’s turning from an easterly heading (no error) onto a northerly heading (biggest error). As we are not turning on a heading that is midway between two cardinal points, there is no need to apply the second formula. Therefore, you will need to overshoot the heading by: (Bank angle + Lat) ÷ 2 = (10 + 50) ÷ 2 = 30° Step 4: Add/subtract the angle found in step 3 to find the angle at which you should stop the turn so that the compass indicated the desired heading: The desired heading is 000°, and in order to stop the turn at 000°, you need to undershoot this heading by 30°:000 + 30 = 030° Note: We are adding here because undershooting 000° means stopping the turn before passing this value on your compass. Since you turn anticlockwise, the heading values decrease, so you need to add the angle found in step 3 to find the correct undershooting angle.

content.question:
An aircraft, flying at 20°N latitude, executes a left turn from 045° Magnetic Heading (MH) to 315° (MH). The pilot reads the MH indication from a Direct Reading Magnetic Compass (DRMC). Before commencing the turn, what should the pilot take into consideration?
1. He/she should roll out when the DRMC reads 335°, to read 315° MH with the wings level
2. He/she should roll out when the DRMC reads 295°, to read 315° MH with the wings level
3. The turning error of the DRMC increases as the bank angle increases
4. A timed turn would be more practical to execute; it would take 30 seconds with a rate-1 turn
5. A timed turn would be more practical to execute; it would take 90 seconds with a rate-1 turn

key_points: Turning errors are greater on North/South headings and at high latitudes as they are directly related to the vertical component of the magnetic field of the Earth

An easy way to remember the turning errors is by using the acronym ‘UNOS’: • UN – Undershoot = Under-turn North • OS – Overshoot = Over-turn South In this case, we will have to under-turn, since we are on the northern half of the compass
If the desired magnetic heading is 315°, we should under-turn by roughly 20° (335°)
learning.explanation: Turning errors are greater on North/South headings and at high latitudes as they are directly related to the vertical component of the magnetic field of the Earth. An easy way to remember the turning errors is by using the acronym ‘UNOS’: • UN – Undershoot = Under-turn North • OS – Overshoot = Over-turn South In this case, we will have to under-turn, since we are on the northern half of the compass. If the desired magnetic heading is 315°, we should under-turn by roughly 20° (335°). This will make the compass read a value of 315° once wings are level. A standard turn equals 3°/sec. Since we are turning through 90°, it would take us 30 seconds.

content.question:
How can you describe a bar magnet?
1. Opposite poles attract
2. The North pole of a freely suspended bar magnet would turn towards North, which is a South magnetic pole
3. Magnetic force is strongest in the centre of the magnet
4. Magnetic force is strongest a short way in from the poles of the magnet
5. Opposite poles repel
6. A freely suspended magnet would dip down towards the near pole

key_points: A magnet is a body that attracts or repels other magnetisable bodies depending on the magnetic moment of their elementary particles, obtained through their spin
The extreme ends of the magnet represent the areas where most of the magnetic field lines are concentrated and are referred to as its magnetic poles
By definition, the pole where field lines exit the body is called its north pole, and the pole where they re-enter the material is called its south pole
learning.explanation: A magnet is a body that attracts or repels other magnetisable bodies depending on the magnetic moment of their elementary particles, obtained through their spin. The extreme ends of the magnet represent the areas where most of the magnetic field lines are concentrated and are referred to as its magnetic poles. By definition, the pole where field lines exit the body is called its north pole, and the pole where they re-enter the material is called its south pole. A magnetic body that is placed in a foreign magnetic field always aligns itself in a specific way; opposing poles attract one another, whereas identical poles repel each other. A freely suspended magnet always rests in the north-south direction because the magnetic south pole of the earth lies in the geographic north direction and the magnetic north pole of the earth lies in the geographical south direction.

content.question: The charted values of magnetic variation on Earth normally change annually due to…

options.A: an increasing field strength causing numerical values at all locations to increase.
options.B: magnetic pole movement causing numerical values at all locations to increase or decrease.
options.C: a reducing field strength causing numerical values at all locations to decrease.
options.D: magnetic pole movement causing numerical values at all locations to increase.

key_points: The magnetic variation is caused by the different locations of the geographic (true) North Pole and the magnetic North Pole
The horizontal component of the Earth’s magnetic field is the part that is detected by the compass needle in order to determine Magnetic North
Therefore, it is accurate enough to say that variation is the angle between the horizontal component of the magnetic field and the true north direction
learning.explanation: The magnetic variation is caused by the different locations of the geographic (true) North Pole and the magnetic North Pole. The horizontal component of the Earth’s magnetic field is the part that is detected by the compass needle in order to determine Magnetic North. Therefore, it is accurate enough to say that variation is the angle between the horizontal component of the magnetic field and the true north direction. At a specific location, the value of magnetic variation varies slowly over time. In fact, the magnetic pole is constantly moving, causing the values at all locations to increase or decrease. This periodic change is also reflected in the slow movement of the magnetic poles monitored through the various ground and satellite-based stations/instruments. The IRS of the aircraft also contains a variation program. It is supplied to the IRS true North to obtain a magnetic heading, which is ultimately fed to the FMS. The IRS is also normally recalibrated from time to time so that it can maintain the variation accurately enough. Lately, the magnetic pole location is changing more rapidly, approximately at a rate of 30 to 40 miles per year, moving towards Siberia. The need to continuously monitor and update the magnetic variation charts is, therefore, more crucial than ever.

content.question: In the Northern Hemisphere, during deceleration following a landing in a southerly direction, a direct reading magnetic compass indicates…

options.A: an apparent turn to the east.
options.C: an apparent turn to the west.
options.D: an apparent turn to the north.

key_points: The compass is subject to acceleration/deceleration and turning errors
Therefore, you can only have a precise indication in straight and level flight
The magnet inside the compass is a pendulous system and is attached to the aircraft at the pivot point
learning.explanation: The compass is subject to acceleration/deceleration and turning errors. Therefore, you can only have a precise indication in straight and level flight. The magnet inside the compass is a pendulous system and is attached to the aircraft at the pivot point. When the aircraft accelerates on a westerly/easterly heading, the magnet will lag behind due to its inertia as the acceleration will act on the magnet’s center of gravity. Therefore, it will momentarily indicate a turn and the heading indication will erroneously change. There will be no error when accelerating/decelerating in a southerly/northerly direction as this will take place in the direction of the Earth’s magnetic flux lines. An easy way to remember the acceleration errors is by using the acronym ‘ANDS’: AN – Accelerate = apparent turn to the North. DS – Decelerate = apparent turn to the South.

key_points: The pendulous magnet inside the direct reading magnetic compass will align itself with the magnetic flux lines of the Earth’s magnetic field

They’re straight and horizontal close to the Equator, but the higher the latitude, the more these lines tend to converge towards the Earth’s poles
learning.explanation: The pendulous magnet inside the direct reading magnetic compass will align itself with the magnetic flux lines of the Earth’s magnetic field. But these magnetic lines are not straight lines spread equally around the Earth. They’re straight and horizontal close to the Equator, but the higher the latitude, the more these lines tend to converge towards the Earth’s poles. Therefore, they will become more and more inclined until being fully vertical at the pole. As a consequence, the pendulous magnet will also increasingly tilt towards its vertical, as the compass approaches the pole. The turning errors are directly related to the vertical component of the magnetic field of the Earth. The higher the dip angle induced by the vertical component, the larger the turning errors.

content.question: The location of the Earth`s magnetic poles…

options.A: is the same as the geographical poles.
options.B: periodically wander (as much as 15 km every year).
options.C: is static in time with respect to the geographical poles.

key_points: The Earth has a magnetic field that has the same properties as any other simple magnet you may have seen
Because of this, the Earth’s magnetic field consists of magnetic field lines flowing from one pole to another
These lines have some properties that are very important to understand as they greatly affect our navigation on Earth and thus, our navigation instruments such as the magnetic compass
learning.explanation: The Earth has a magnetic field that has the same properties as any other simple magnet you may have seen. Because of this, the Earth’s magnetic field consists of magnetic field lines flowing from one pole to another. These lines have some properties that are very important to understand as they greatly affect our navigation on Earth and thus, our navigation instruments such as the magnetic compass. In fact, these magnetic lines are not straight lines spread equally around the Earth. They are straight and horizontal close to the equator, but the higher the latitude, the more these lines tend to converge towards the Earth’s poles. Therefore, they will become more and more inclined until being fully vertical at the pole. As a consequence, the pendulous magnet will also increasingly tilt towards its vertical and produce greater instrument errors (turning, acceleration…). The magnetic lines converge at the magnetic poles, which is different from the geographic pole (the axis around which the Earth is spinning). Another to consider is that the magnetic poles continuously change location. For instance, right now the magnetic North pole is situated approximately in Northern Canada, but it is moving at a rate of about 50km/year towards Siberia. On the other hand, the South magnetic pole is moving at around 15 km/year, the same rate at which the North magnetic pole used to move as well as a few years ago.

content.question: What circumstances would require a compass swinging procedure?

options.A: After a flight during which there was an interruption to the aircrafts electrical supply.
options.B: After a flight during which the aircraft was hit by lightning.
options.C: After a flight at an extremely high magnetic latitude.
options.D: After a flight across the agonic line.

key_points: Compass swing is the process of assessing deviation caused by various factors like magnetic materials, electrical currents, and the airframe

The goals of a compass swing are to identify deviations between magnetic north (observed on a landing compass) and compass north (observed in the aircraft) across various headings; correct / remove as much deviation as possible and document the remaining residual deviation post-adjustment
Occasions for Swinging the Compass When compass components are installed or replaced
learning.explanation: Compass swing is the process of assessing deviation caused by various factors like magnetic materials, electrical currents, and the airframe. The goals of a compass swing are to identify deviations between magnetic north (observed on a landing compass) and compass north (observed in the aircraft) across various headings; correct / remove as much deviation as possible and document the remaining residual deviation post-adjustment. Occasions for Swinging the Compass When compass components are installed or replaced. Whenever the accuracy of the compass is in doubt. After a maintenance inspection if required by the placarded schedule. After a significant aircraft modification, repair or replacement involving magnetic material. When carrying unusual ferromagnetic payloads. When the compass has been subjected to significant shock. If the aircraft has been struck by lightning (*) After significant modification to aircraft radio/electrical systems. After the aircraft has been given a new base of operations if the move involves a large change of magnetic latitude. If the aircraft has been in long term storage resting on one heading. (*) The aircraft's magnetic field results from both hard and soft iron components, as well as electrical circuits. While hard iron components typically have stable magnetic properties, lightning strikes can remagnetize them, leading to different deviations.

The deviation in different magnetic directions is obtain with the aircraft on the ground and comparing the aircraft's compass reading with the magnetic north. A small card is placed next to the magnetic compass to alert the pilot about corrections needed to be made on a compass indication to maintain a certain magnetic heading. After the aircraft has been given a new theatre of operations if the move involves a large change of magnetic latitude. If the aircraft has been in long term storage standing on one heading. When a new compass is fitted. Upon delivery of a new aircraft.

key_points: The compass is subject to acceleration/deceleration and turning errors
Therefore, you can only have a precise indication in straight and level flight
The magnet inside the compass is a pendulous system and is attached to the aircraft at the pivot point
learning.explanation: The compass is subject to acceleration/deceleration and turning errors. Therefore, you can only have a precise indication in straight and level flight. The magnet inside the compass is a pendulous system and is attached to the aircraft at the pivot point. When the aircraft accelerates on a westerly/easterly heading, the magnet will lag behind due to its inertia as the acceleration will act on the magnet’s center of gravity. Therefore, it will momentarily indicate a turn and the heading indication will erroneously change. There will be no error when accelerating/decelerating in a southerly/northerly direction as this will take place in the direction of the Earth’s magnetic flux lines. An easy way to remember the acceleration errors is by using the acronym ‘ANDS’: AN – Accelerate = apparent turn to the North. DS – Decelerate = apparent turn to the South.

The compass’ needle will align itself with the Earth's horizontal component (H) of the Earth's magnetic field. The compass is ineffective near the poles. As you approach the poles, the angle between magnetic flux and the horizon becomes vertical – compass ‘dip’ becomes a factor => decrease in horizontal magnetic field, increase in vertical magnetic field. The value of the horizontal component is maximum at the Magnetic Equator (=midway between the two poles). learning.explanation: The gyromagnetic compass is the combination of a simple compass and a gyroscope. The indications of the magnetic compass are stabilized by the gyroscope to reduce the effects of acceleration and turning errors. The main components of a gyromagnetic compass are the flux valve, the heading indicator, the slaving amplifier, the synchronizing motor, and the horizontal gyro. The flux valve (=flux detection unit) senses the Earth’s magnetic field which is compared to the position of the drive shaft connecting the horizontal gyro and the heading indicator. Anytime the gyro has drifted, and its position would differ from the flux valve field, an AC error signal is transmitted to the precession amplifier. Before being converted into a DC signal, the AC signal is first amplified, and phase detected. This signal drives the precession motor that will realign the gyro. The new position is compared again, and the synchronization will continue until the heading indicator is synchronized. The flux valve is usually remotely located in the wingtip or the fin of the aircraft to be free of any magnetic disturbances. An easy way to remember the order of the gyromagnetic compass operation is by using the acronym ‘FEAT’: Flux valve => Error detector => Amplifier => Torque motor

content.question: A direct reading compass (DRC) at the magnetic North Pole...

options.A: is as accurate as in Equator.
options.B: aligns with the vertical component Z of the Earth’s magnetic field.
options.C: aligns with the horizontal component H of the Earth’s magnetic field.
options.D: is inoperative because the true north and magnetic north variation is too high.

key_points: EASA learning objective 022
learning.explanation: EASA learning objective 022.03.01.01.04 states: Describe that a magnetic compass will align itself to both the horizontal (azimuth) and vertical (dip) components of the Earth’s magnetic field, thus will not function in the vicinity of the magnetic poles. The Earths magnetic field can be resolved into two components; horizontal (H) and vertical (Z). It can be seen from the figure that the lines of magnetism are not horizontal as they move away from the equator, the angle between the field line and the local horizontal is called dip. Dip increases as you get closer to the magnetic poles because the H component gets weaker and the Z component gets stronger. At the magnetic poles dip is 90° due to the lack of any H component. A freely suspended compass needle works by detecting the horizontal field component so is very accurate at the Equator where H is maximum. As you approach the magnetic poles, the horizontal component becomes so weak that the DRC will attempt to align with the vertical component Z of the Earth's magnetic field. Theoretically a compass needle would point vertically downwards at the magnetic pole but the compass assembly in a DRC is mounted inside a casing. Eventually an angle of dip will be reached where the rotating compass assembly is unable to move as it makes contact with the case, rendering it unuseable. Note: It's true to say that the variation at the magnetic north pole is very high (up to 180°), but that's not what renders the DRC inoperative.

Magnetic heading: 220°

learning.explanation: The operating principles of direct reading compasses are based on the fundamentals of magnetism, in particular the interaction between the magnetic field of a suitably suspended magnetic element, and the Earth’s magnetic field. content.question: When accelerating on a westerly heading in the northern hemisphere, the compass card of a direct reading magnetic compass will turn…

options.A: clockwise giving an apparent turn towards the North.
options.B: anti-clockwise giving an apparent turn towards the North.
options.C: clockwise giving an apparent turn towards the South.
options.D: anti-clockwise giving an apparent turn towards the South.

key_points: The compass is subject to acceleration/deceleration and turning errors
Therefore, you can only have a precise indication in straight and level flight
The magnet inside the compass is a pendulous system and is attached to the aircraft at the pivot point
learning.explanation: The compass is subject to acceleration/deceleration and turning errors. Therefore, you can only have a precise indication in straight and level flight. The magnet inside the compass is a pendulous system and is attached to the aircraft at the pivot point. When the aircraft accelerates on a westerly/easterly heading, the magnet will lag behind due to its inertia as the acceleration will act on the magnet’s center of gravity. Therefore, it will momentarily indicate a turn and the heading indication will erroneously change. There will be no error when accelerating/decelerating in a southerly/northerly direction as this will take place in the direction of the Earth’s magnetic flux lines. An easy way to remember the acceleration errors is by using the acronym ‘ANDS’: AN – Accelerate = apparent turn to the North. DS – Decelerate = apparent turn to the South. In order to visualize in which direction is the compass card turning, try to imagine a simple turn without considering the acceleration error. The magnet inside the compass case is always ‘North seeking’, so it will always remain in a steady position. The compass heading indications will change because the airplane is turning around the compass card and not the opposite. If you are on a westerly heading, and you turn to the North - the airplane will turn clockwise around the compass card. As a consequence, the opposite is true => we can say that the compass card has turned anticlockwise as the airplane made a turn towards the North.

key_points: The gyro-magnetic compass is the combination of a simple compass and a gyroscope
The indications of the magnetic compass are stabilized by the gyroscope to reduce the effects of acceleration and turning errors
The main components of a gyromagnetic compass are the flux valve, the heading indicator, the slaving amplifier, the synchronizing motor, and the horizontal gyro
learning.explanation: The gyro-magnetic compass is the combination of a simple compass and a gyroscope. The indications of the magnetic compass are stabilized by the gyroscope to reduce the effects of acceleration and turning errors. The main components of a gyromagnetic compass are the flux valve, the heading indicator, the slaving amplifier, the synchronizing motor, and the horizontal gyro. The flux valve senses the Earth’s magnetic field which is compared to the position of the drive shaft connecting the horizontal gyro and the heading indicator. Anytime the gyro has drifted, and its position would differ from the flux valve field, an AC error signal is transmitted to the precession amplifier. Before being converted into a DC signal, the AC signal is first amplified, and phase detected. This signal drives the precession motor that will realign the gyro. The new position is compared again, and the synchronization will continue until the heading indicator is synchronized. The flux valve is usually remotely located in the wingtip or the fin of the aircraft to be free of any magnetic disturbances.

learning.explanation: Gyro-magnetic Compass - Basic System Description At its simplest, the system comprises the following elements: - Magnetic Detector Unit. This is also often known as a flux valve or a flux detector. - Heading Indicator. - Precession Amplifier. - Precession Motor. - Horizontal Gyro. The detector unit (flux valve) senses the earth’s magnetic field and reproduces it within the compass unit, where it is compared with the position of the gyro drive shaft. If the two are aligned, no further action takes place. The compass card is reading the right heading. If the magnetic input from the flux valve should fail or if it becomes unreliable due to proximity to one of the earth’s magnetic poles, it is possible to operate the gyro-magnetic compass in gyro mode only, in which case it acts as a DGI and will need to be re-set periodically to a directional reference such as a standby compass or other source of aircraft heading. When it operates as a DGI, this is referred to as FREE mode, whilst its normal magnetically monitored operation is referred to as SLAVED mode.

content.question: What is the value of the magnetic dip at the magnetic South Pole?

key_points: The Earth has a magnetic field that has the same properties as any other simple magnet you may have seen
Because of this, the Earth’s magnetic field consists of magnetic field lines flowing from one pole to another
These lines have some properties that are very important to understand as they greatly affect our navigation on Earth and thus, our navigation instruments such as the magnetic compass
learning.explanation: The Earth has a magnetic field that has the same properties as any other simple magnet you may have seen. Because of this, the Earth’s magnetic field consists of magnetic field lines flowing from one pole to another. These lines have some properties that are very important to understand as they greatly affect our navigation on Earth and thus, our navigation instruments such as the magnetic compass. In fact, these magnetic lines are not straight lines spread equally around the Earth. They are straight and horizontal close to the equator, but the higher the latitude, the more these lines tend to converge towards the Earth’s poles. Therefore, they will become more and more inclined until being fully vertical at the pole. The angle between the horizontal plane and the vertical component of the magnetic field lines of the Earth is called the dip angle. The dip angle will have a value of almost 90° at the poles (increased vertical magnetic field) and will be almost null at the equator (low vertical component – high horizontal component). As a consequence, the pendulous magnet will also increasingly tilt towards its vertical and produce greater instrument errors (turning, acceleration…).

Given deviation table of a direct reading compass:

Steer 359 030 061 092 121 150 178 209 242 272 298 331

key_points: Use the acronym C-D-M-V-T, and replace the values you are given in the question: 242° – D – M – 22°E – T You are also given a deviation table that will allow you to find the magnetic heading

The value above 242°, in the ‘to fly’ line is 240°
learning.explanation: Use the acronym C-D-M-V-T, and replace the values you are given in the question: 242° – D – M – 22°E – T You are also given a deviation table that will allow you to find the magnetic heading. You’re currently maintaining a compass heading of 242°, therefore you look for this value in the lower line of the deviation table. The value above 242°, in the ‘to fly’ line is 240°. This means that while maintaining a compass indication of 242°, you are flying in reality on a magnetic heading of 240°. Our acronym becomes now as follows: 242° - D – 240° - 22°E - T You don’t really need to find the deviation because you already have the magnetic heading and the variation. Thanks to the acronym CADET you can easily find the true heading of the aircraft. Moving from the left to the right of the acronym, you need to add if the variation is East (CADET = AD (add) E (east)). In our case, the variation is East, therefore you need to add the 22°E variation to the magnetic heading to obtain a True heading of 262°. It is not needed, nor asked in this question to find the deviation. But you can do it anyway to exercise the two acronyms and get better at solving this type of question. Thanks to the acronym CADET you can easily deduce that the variation is 2°W. In fact, in the direction from C (compass) to T (true) you need to add the deviation whenever it is E (east). In our case we initially have a value of 242° and moving to the right of the acronym (towards T=true), you obtain a value of 240° magnetic heading - the difference hasn’t been added but subtracted. Therefore, the deviation is West.

key_points: A freely suspended magnet will align itself with the Earth's magnetic field
The total field (T) is resolved into a horizontal component (H) and a vertical component (Z)

HORIZONTAL COMPONENT The horizontal component (H) of the earth’s field is known as the directive force and it is the component which aligns the magnetic compass needle with the magnetic meridian (providing a directional reference)
learning.explanation: A freely suspended magnet will align itself with the Earth's magnetic field. The total field (T) is resolved into a horizontal component (H) and a vertical component (Z). HORIZONTAL COMPONENT The horizontal component (H) of the earth’s field is known as the directive force and it is the component which aligns the magnetic compass needle with the magnetic meridian (providing a directional reference). Near the magnetic poles, the vertical component becomes much greater than at lower latitudes where the horizontal component dominates. This leads to needles or cards in compasses being pulled downwards towards the ground, getting caught or dragging instead of turning freely in the horizontal plane. The horizontal component approaches zero over the poles => With a horizontal component which is too weak, compass performance becomes sluggish and inaccurate. content.question: When decelerating on a westerly heading in the Northern Hemisphere, the compass card of a direct reading magnetic compass turns…

options.A: clockwise giving an apparent turn towards the North.
options.B: anti-clockwise giving an apparent turn towards the North.
options.C: anti-clockwise giving an apparent turn towards the South.
options.D: clockwise giving an apparent turn toward the South.

key_points: The compass is subject to acceleration/deceleration and turning errors
Therefore, you can only have a precise indication in straight and level flight
The magnet inside the compass is a pendulous system and is attached to the aircraft at the pivot point
learning.explanation: The compass is subject to acceleration/deceleration and turning errors. Therefore, you can only have a precise indication in straight and level flight. The magnet inside the compass is a pendulous system and is attached to the aircraft at the pivot point. When the aircraft accelerates on a westerly/easterly heading, the magnet will lag behind due to its inertia as the acceleration will act on the magnet’s center of gravity. Therefore, it will momentarily indicate a turn and the heading indication will erroneously change. There will be no error when accelerating/decelerating in a southerly/northerly direction as this will take place in the direction of the Earth’s magnetic flux lines. An easy way to remember the acceleration errors is by using the acronym ‘ANDS’: AN – Accelerate = apparent turn to the North. DS – Decelerate = apparent turn to the South. In order to visualize in which direction is the compass card turning, try to imagine a simple turn without considering the acceleration error. The magnet inside the compass case is always ‘North seeking’, so it will always remain in a steady position. The compass heading indications will change because the airplane is turning around the compass card and not the opposite. If you are on a westerly heading, and you turn to the South - the airplane will turn anticlockwise around the compass card. As a consequence, the opposite is true => we can say that the compass card has turned clockwise as the airplane made a turn towards the South.

learning.explanation: Imagine the situation: you are heading East, and you start to increase your bank angle. Initially, the pendulous magnet inside your compass will still remain aligned with the magnetic North of the Earth. However, as you increase the bank angle even more, the dip, which is the angle between the horizontal plane and your magnet, will get increasingly higher. At some point, when the bank angle gets too big, the compass will just ‘fall’ and rotate 180° towards the lowest wing which is into the turn, and the compass will indicate West instead of East. Therefore, the total error of the compass would be 180° on an easterly heading in a steep right turn. Conclusion: beyond the critical bank angle (90 minus the dip angle), the compass will lag by 180 degrees when the aircraft is banked towards the equator. content.question: On the Earth, a line of magnetic latitude is a line joining points of equal.

key_points: Magnetic dip is the natural phenomenon of the vertical component of the magnetic field over the earth's surface and its effect on the magnetic compass

The earth's magnetic field has two components or forces: a horizontal force parallel to the earth's surface that is used to align the compass with magnetic north and therefore to determine direction and a vertical force that causes the needle to dip down

learning.explanation: Magnetic dip is the natural phenomenon of the vertical component of the magnetic field over the earth's surface and its effect on the magnetic compass. The earth's magnetic field has two components or forces: a horizontal force parallel to the earth's surface that is used to align the compass with magnetic north and therefore to determine direction and a vertical force that causes the needle to dip down. At the magnetic equator, the horizontal force is dominant, and therefore, there is no dip and the compass is accurate. However, as you move closer to either of the magnetic poles, the vertical component increases, and this induces the magnetic bar in the compass to dip down to align itself vertically with the magnetic field. Lines joining points of equal dip are called isoclinic lines, or magnetic latitudes. There is a magnetic latitude roughly near the equator where the dip is zero (referred to as aclinic line).

learning.explanation: The Earth has a magnetic field that has the same properties as any other simple magnet you may have seen. Because of this, the Earth’s magnetic field consists of magnetic field lines flowing from one pole to another. These lines have some properties that are very important to understand as they greatly affect our navigation on Earth and thus, our navigation instruments such as the magnetic compass. In fact, these magnetic lines are not straight lines spread equally around the Earth. They are straight and horizontal close to the equator, but the higher the latitude, the more these lines tend to converge towards the Earth’s poles. Therefore, they will become more and more inclined until being fully vertical at the pole. As a consequence, the pendulous magnet will also increasingly tilt towards its vertical and produce greater instrument errors (turning, acceleration…). The magnetic lines converge at the magnetic poles, which is different from the geographic pole (the axis around which the Earth is spinning). Another thing to consider is that the magnetic poles continuously change location. For instance, right now the magnetic North pole is situated approximately in Northern Canada, but it is moving at a rate of about 50km/year towards Siberia. On the other hand, the South magnetic pole is moving at around 15 km/year, the same rate at which the North magnetic pole used to move as well as a few years ago.

The compass’ needle will align itself with the Earth's horizontal component (H) of the Earth's magnetic field. The compass is ineffective near the poles. As you approach the poles, the angle between magnetic flux and the horizon becomes vertical – compass ‘dip’ becomes a factor => decrease in horizontal magnetic field, increase in vertical magnetic field. The value of the horizontal component is maximum at the Magnetic Equator, a freely suspended compass needle in the Earth's magnetic field will be horizontal to the Earth - in line with the horizontal component.

content.question:
In a three-phase synchronous motor type tachometer:
1 – the transmitter is a direct current generator
2 – the voltage is proportional to the transmitter drive speed
3 – the frequency is proportional to the transmitter drive speed
4 – the speed indicating element is a galvanometer
5 – the speed indicating element is an asynchronous motor driving a magnetic tachometer
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: Synchronous motors consist of a stator and a rotor
The stator's field coil is excited by a 3-phase alternate current, and the rotor is a basic permanent magnet
The rotor poles will attract the opposite poles of the stator’s rotating magnetic field and will rotate at the same speed, or in other words, at synchronous speed
learning.explanation: Synchronous motors consist of a stator and a rotor. The stator's field coil is excited by a 3-phase alternate current, and the rotor is a basic permanent magnet. The rotor poles will attract the opposite poles of the stator’s rotating magnetic field and will rotate at the same speed, or in other words, at synchronous speed. If the rotor has no initial rotation force, the opposite poles’ attraction force won’t be enough to rotate the rotor and self-start the motor. In this case, a ‘squirrel cage’ will be fitted to the rotor so that it can be rotated by the electromagnetic field of the stator (supplied by 3 phase AC). When the rotor reaches its maximum speed, it will get energized and synchronized with the stator’s opposite poles to rotate at a synchronous speed. However, until the rotor becomes synchronized with the stator’s opposite poles, the squirrel cage is asynchronous. It is basically an inductive system since electricity is introduced to the rotor by magnetic induction rather than direct electric supply, and inductive systems are asynchronous by their operating principle as described above. It is believed that in this question, the examiner wants to highlight that the squirrel cage is asynchronous and the motor itself has a synchronous operation. A permanent magnet is linked through a shaft to the rotor of the synchronous motor and is rotating in an aluminum drag cup. Eddy currents with their own magnetic field are generated by the rotating magnet and act on the electrons of the drag cup. The interaction between the magnetic fields produced by the Eddy currents and the magnet's magnetic field produces a turning force that will turn the drag cup in the permanent magnet's direction. A small shaft connects the drag cup with a hairspring and a pointer calibrated to indicate the RPM on a dial. The frequency of the AC supplied to the synchronous motor is proportional to the engine’s RPM. Therefore, the higher the RPM, the higher the current supplied to the motor and also the torque resulting from the magnet rotating inside the drag-cup. The hairspring opposes the turning force to control the indication of the pointer.

content.question: On a multi-engine aircraft, a synchroscope provides an indication of the difference in…

key_points: On propeller-driven multiengine aircraft, even a slight difference in RPM can create uncomfortable noise and vibrations
You can realize that engine RPMs are not synchronized during the flight if you hear a strange intermittent beat
The RPM indicator only allows the pilot to set the RPM roughly, but discrepancies in engines’ speed can be hard to adjust
learning.explanation: On propeller-driven multiengine aircraft, even a slight difference in RPM can create uncomfortable noise and vibrations. You can realize that engine RPMs are not synchronized during the flight if you hear a strange intermittent beat. The RPM indicator only allows the pilot to set the RPM roughly, but discrepancies in engines’ speed can be hard to adjust. To overcome this problem, some aircraft are fitted with an instrument called a synchroscope. In a synchroscope, one engine is identified as the master, and the others are the slaves. The instrument indicates on a dial by means of a pointer, the variation in RPM relative to the master engine. Generally, the synchroscopes use each engine's tachometers to convert the rotational speed into an electrical current. In this way, if the slave engine is turning faster, it produces a bigger current, and the pointer will turn in a given direction. If the slave engine is rotating slower, the current provided to the synchroscope will be lower, and the pointer will turn in the opposite direction. Synchroscopes may have different operating principles; some may work based on a supplied voltage; others may compare each engine's alternators' frequencies. Modern propeller-driven multiengine airplanes have their engine RPMs automatically synchronized through various control units.

learning.explanation: The electronic torquemeter consists of two coaxial shafts both fitted with a toothed gear (exciter wheel) at their end. learning.explanation: The float-type fuel gauging system consists of a simple mechanical float sitting on the fuel level, linked via a mechanical arm to a gauge indicating the volume. The reading will also be imprecise during maneuvers, accelerations, and turbulence; the reading will only be reliable in straight and level flight. learning.explanation: The magnetic tachometer is one of the simplest types of tachometer possible. The crankshaft of the engine drives a rotating shaft, ending in a permanent magnet rotating inside an aluminum drag cup. Eddy currents with their own magnetic field are generated by the rotating magnet and act on the electrons of the drag cup. The interaction between the magnetic fields produced by the Eddy currents and the magnet's magnetic field produces a turning force that will try to turn the drag cup in the permanent magnet's direction. The spring on the drag cup means that we can measure the amount of force produced by the interaction, as the drag cup will turn to a point where its force is at equilibrium against the spring compression. The force is a direct indicator of the RPM. A small shaft connects the drag cup with a hairspring and a pointer calibrated to indicate the RPM on a dial. Therefore, the higher the RPM, the larger the eddy currents, and the higher the torque on the drag cup. The hairspring opposes this turning force to control the indication of the pointer.

learning.explanation: SYNCHROSCOPE Even a slight difference in RPM can create uncomfortable noise, oscillations and vibrations. content.question: Concerning the thrust measurement, the N1 is defined as the…

key_points: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow
On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR
The N1, displayed to the pilots as a percentage, is nothing else than the compressor’s first stage (the fan) rotation speed
learning.explanation: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow. On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR. The N1, displayed to the pilots as a percentage, is nothing else than the compressor’s first stage (the fan) rotation speed. In a modern gas turbine engine such as the CFM 56 fitted to the B737 or A320, the engine has two compressor turbine assemblies. Each assembly is mounted on a common shaft. The first one is a Low Pressure compressor turbine assembly, and the second one is the High Pressure compressor turbine assembly. The first part of the engine is the fan, which divides the incoming airflow into two streams. The first stream is directed to the next compressor stages for further compression and combustion. The rest of the airflow is accelerated around the core, providing most of the engine thrust. Be careful! The wording of the question is very misleading. You need to remember what a compressor stage is. One stage in a compressor consists of a rotating disk of rotor blades followed by the stator's stationary blades. Usually, manufacturers refer to the first stage of the LP compressor as the bypass fan (see the attached picture of the PW-1000 G engine). We agree that both ‘first stage compressor speed’ and ‘low pressure shaft speed’ are correct answers as the fan is technically the first stage of the LP compressor. However, the examiner most probably wants to point-out the difference between the fan and the next stages of the LP compressor as it has a slightly different function than the rest of the LP compressor stages (division of the airflow into two different streams). Therefore, the whole scope of the provided correct answer is to stress that the N1 is defined as the fan’s speed. Note: This is the correct answer indicated by EASA at the official instrumentation exam according to other students’ feedback. Please, don’t hesitate to send us your feedback if you get this question at your official exam so that we can update the wording and/or edit the explanation accordingly.

The EPR is the ratio between the turbine discharge pressure (measured at the low-pressure turbine exhaust, which is the last stage of the engine) and the compressor inlet pressure (measured at the engine’s inlet, usually the first or second stage).

content.question: During take-off, the front probe of an EPR system becomes blocked by ingested debris or icing but the rear probe remains unaffected. The displayed EPR will likely be…

options.A: equal to zero, and N1 should be used instead.
options.B: lower than the actual EPR value.
options.C: higher than the actual EPR value.
options.D: equal to the LP turbine exhaust pressure.

key_points: Engine Pressure Ratio (EPR) The thrust of jet engines can be controlled using the engine pressure ratio (EPR)
The ration is determined by dividing the pressure at the exhaust nozzle (turbine outlet pressure) by the pressure at the compressor entry
Both these pressures are measured by pitot tubes
learning.explanation: Engine Pressure Ratio (EPR) The thrust of jet engines can be controlled using the engine pressure ratio (EPR). The ration is determined by dividing the pressure at the exhaust nozzle (turbine outlet pressure) by the pressure at the compressor entry. Both these pressures are measured by pitot tubes. Consequently, should any of these sensors fail or the signal cannot be transferred, the indicated EPR will be different than the actual EPR. During take-off, the aircraft accelerates and the engine intake pressure will increase due to the increased forward speed. When at some point the pressure sensor on the compressor inlet becomes blocked, it cannot sense the higher intake pressure, but continues to report the low pressure at the time of blockage. The outlet pressure increases, and the sensor which is unaffected by the blockage can measure that. The turbine outlet pressure is divided by a too low compressor inlet pressure, and the result is higher than the actual EPR.

options.D: A red flag in the gauge.

key_points: CAPACITANCE TYPE FUEL GAUGING SYSTEM The working principle of a capacitance-type fuel gauging system is based on the variation of the capacitor’s dielectric
The dielectric is the solution found between the two plates of the capacitor, so in our system, they are the fuel and the air
The plates of the capacitor can hold only a certain amount of electric charge
learning.explanation: CAPACITANCE TYPE FUEL GAUGING SYSTEM The working principle of a capacitance-type fuel gauging system is based on the variation of the capacitor’s dielectric. The dielectric is the solution found between the two plates of the capacitor, so in our system, they are the fuel and the air. The plates of the capacitor can hold only a certain amount of electric charge. This amount depends on the distance between the two plates, the area of the plates and the insulating properties of the dielectric. In contrast to a float system, capacitance type fuel gauges measure fuel mass, which is directly proportional to the contained amount of energy. In case of a malfunction, the capacitance would reduce to zero, causing the fuel gauge to indicate “empty”.

content.question:
The different types of tachometer are:
1 – electrical
2 – mechanical
3 – electronic
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: There are 3 types of tachometers currently in use: the electrical, electronic, and mechanical tachometer
The electrical tachometer is basically a 3 phase AC tacho-generator driven by the engine
It is usually situated in the gearbox, close to the engine-driven generator
learning.explanation: There are 3 types of tachometers currently in use: the electrical, electronic, and mechanical tachometer. The electrical tachometer is basically a 3 phase AC tacho-generator driven by the engine. It is usually situated in the gearbox, close to the engine-driven generator. The current fed by the generator is fed to the indicator consisting of a synchronous motor driving a magnet-drag cup assembly that moves a pointer over a scale. The electronic tachometer is a simpler system requiring less wiring and can be fitted on any of the engine’s rotating parts. It consists of a small electromagnet probe (inductive probe) that detects the passage of a notched wheel mounted on the compressor or turbine shaft. When the notched wheel passes in front of the probe, it alters its magnetic field. The frequency at which the magnetic field of the probe is altered is directly related to the rotation speed of the compressor. The mechanical tachometer works on the same drag cup assembly principle as its successor, the tacho-generator. A shaft directly connected to the engine drives a permanent magnet in a drag cup. The main disadvantage of this system is that the shaft connecting the engine and the permanent magnet cannot be too long, usually only about 2m. Therefore, it cannot be fitted on aircraft other than light airplanes where the engine is close to the cockpit.

The noise can be uncomfortable for the flight/cabin crew and the passengers. Continuous exposure to vibrations may induce early fatigue to the airframe. Achieve symmetrical thrust and fuel consumption – INCORRECT. This statement is a bit unclear as technically if you synchronize your engine RPMs, they will provide symmetrical thrust and the fuel consumption on both engines (or more) is going to be the same. However, the synchroscope is used to synchronize the engines, not the fuel.

key_points: A capacitor consists of two electrically charged plates of the same size, located at a fixed distance from each other
Fuel and air are the dielectrics, so the capacitance between the two plates varies depending on the amount of fuel and air found between the plates

Capacitance is based on the following formula: Capacitance = E x A/D E = dielectric permittivity D = distance between capacitor’s plates A = area of the plates As you can see, only one of these items is variable: the dielectric permittivity
learning.explanation: A capacitor consists of two electrically charged plates of the same size, located at a fixed distance from each other. Fuel and air are the dielectrics, so the capacitance between the two plates varies depending on the amount of fuel and air found between the plates. Capacitance is based on the following formula: Capacitance = E x A/D E = dielectric permittivity D = distance between capacitor’s plates A = area of the plates As you can see, only one of these items is variable: the dielectric permittivity. To put it simple, the dielectric permittivity is a parameter that measures how well an electric field will interact with any given material. Fuel has approximately twice the capacitance of the air, so the current sensed between the capacitor’s plates is going to be proportional to the level of fuel in the tanks.

content.question:
Given:
P = power.
T = torque. n = RPM.
The correct relationship is…

key_points: Power is work done per unit of time
Work is generated when a force is applied to an object and moves it over a certain distance
It is measured in Joules, and 1 Joule = 1 Nm (same unit as torque)
learning.explanation: Power is work done per unit of time. Work is generated when a force is applied to an object and moves it over a certain distance. It is measured in Joules, and 1 Joule = 1 Nm (same unit as torque). The Rotations Per Minute (rpm) define an angular motion over time. Therefore, the product of work generated by a body (Nm) in angular motion over time gives you the power produced by that body. Try to remember the correct formula by using the units of each variable. P = T x n → n = P / T Where: T – torque in Nm N – rotations per minute (1/min) P – Power in Watt (W) Since 1 W = 1 Nm/s, a small conversion needs to be made from rpm (1/min) to rps (1/sec) by using: rpm ÷ 60 = rps

content.question:
Consider two twin-engined, propeller-driven aeroplanes. The propellers on AP1 rotate clockwise, and those on AP2 rotate anticlockwise.
If there's a left engine failure in both aeroplanes, which will give the largest yawing moment, and from which side will it be?

options.A: Aircraft with AP1 produces greater yaw to the left
options.B: Aircraft with AP1 produces greater yaw to the right
options.C: Aircraft with AP2 produces greater yaw to the left
options.D: Aircraft with AP2 produces greater yaw to the right

key_points: When an engine fails on a multi-engine aircraft, there will be a decrease in thrust and an increase in drag on the side of the failed engine
Primarily there will be a yawing moment towards the failed (dead) engine
The critical engine is the engine which would give the biggest yawing moment if it fails
learning.explanation: When an engine fails on a multi-engine aircraft, there will be a decrease in thrust and an increase in drag on the side of the failed engine. Primarily there will be a yawing moment towards the failed (dead) engine. The critical engine is the engine which would give the biggest yawing moment if it fails. One of the factors influencing the yawing moment following an engine failure on a multi-engine aircraft is the length of the thrust arm (i.e., distance from the aircraft's CG to the thrust line of the operating engine). In case of a propeller engine aircraft, the length of the thrust arm is determined by the asymmetric effect of the propeller. When the aircraft is flying with a positive angle of attack (which is normal), the thrust line of a clockwise rotating propeller (when viewed from the rear) is displaced to the right of the engine centre line. This is because the down-going blade generates more thrust than the up-going blade (P-factor). If both engines rotate clockwise, the starboard (right) engine will have a longer thrust arm than the port (left) engine. If the left engine fails, the thrust of the right engine acts through a longer thrust arm and will give a larger yawing moment. If both engines rotate inward, they will have the same (shorter) thrust arm (counter-rotating propellers). Of course, no matter the direction of the propellers, a failure of the left engine will always produce a yaw to the left, it is just bigger if the aircraft has clockwise rotation propellers. Note: Although this question is not part of the instrumentation syllabus, it was added to the database because of student feedback. If you find this question in your INSTRUMENTATION exam, you should appeal.

content.question: On an twin-engine aeroplane, the synchroscope uses the following principle…

options.A: it mathematically subtracts the vibrations of both engines.
options.B: a piezoelectric sensor measures the vibrations on each engine.
options.C: it measures the frequency difference between the two engine driven alternators.
options.D: it mathematically subtracts the RPM of both engines.

key_points: Synchroscopes may have different operating principles; some may work based on a supplied voltage; others may compare each engine's alternators' frequencies
Modern propeller-driven multiengine airplanes have their engine RPMs automatically synchronized through various control units
In a synchroscope, one engine is identified as the master, and the others are the slaves
learning.explanation: Synchroscopes may have different operating principles; some may work based on a supplied voltage; others may compare each engine's alternators' frequencies. Modern propeller-driven multiengine airplanes have their engine RPMs automatically synchronized through various control units. In a synchroscope, one engine is identified as the master, and the others are the slaves. The instrument indicates on a dial using a pointer the variation in RPM relative to the master engine. Generally, the synchroscopes use each engine's tachometers to convert the rotational speed into an electrical current. In this way, if the slave engine is turning faster, it produces a bigger current, and the pointer will turn in a given direction. If the slave engine is rotating slower, the current provided to the synchroscope will be lower, and the pointer will turn in the opposite direction.

key_points: The working principle of a capacitance-type fuel gauging system is based on the variation of the capacitor’s dielectric
The dielectric is the solution found between the two plates of the capacitor, so in our system, they are the fuel and the air
The plates of the capacitor can hold only a certain amount of electric charge
learning.explanation: The working principle of a capacitance-type fuel gauging system is based on the variation of the capacitor’s dielectric. The dielectric is the solution found between the two plates of the capacitor, so in our system, they are the fuel and the air. The plates of the capacitor can hold only a certain amount of electric charge. This amount depends on the distance between the two plates, the area of the plates and the insulating properties of the dielectric. content.question:
The indication of a fuel float gauge varies with:
1 – pitch angle
2 – accelerations
3 – fuel temperature
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: The float-type fuel gauging system consists of a simple mechanical float sitting on the fuel level, linked via a mechanical arm to a gauge indicating the volume
One of the main limitations of the volume indicating systems is that temperature variations will impact the reading of the tanks’ actual fuel quantity
In fact, at warm temperatures, fuel is heated up and expands
learning.explanation: The float-type fuel gauging system consists of a simple mechanical float sitting on the fuel level, linked via a mechanical arm to a gauge indicating the volume. One of the main limitations of the volume indicating systems is that temperature variations will impact the reading of the tanks’ actual fuel quantity. In fact, at warm temperatures, fuel is heated up and expands. Since the volume of fuel is increasing, the float-type gauge indicates an increase of fuel quantity within the tanks. The reading will also be imprecise during maneuvers (pitch angle changes), accelerations, and turbulence; the reading will only be reliable in straight and level flight. To overcome this problem, modern capacitor-type fuel gauging systems are fitted with a density compensating unit, which accounts for the temperature changes by converting the output from volume to mass of fuel.

content.question: In a compensated capacitance type quantity indicating system, the contents gauge of a half-full fuel tank indicates a fuel mass of 8000 kg. If a temperature rise increased the volume of fuel by 5%, the indicated fuel mass would…

key_points: Capacitance type fuel quantity indicators can provide the fuel's mass, in opposition with other fuel gauging systems that may give only the volume
The problem with the volume-based instrument is that it is subject to temperature variations
If the temperature increases, the density will decrease, and fuel volume will increase, which will give false information about the actual usable fuel within the tanks
learning.explanation: Capacitance type fuel quantity indicators can provide the fuel's mass, in opposition with other fuel gauging systems that may give only the volume. The problem with the volume-based instrument is that it is subject to temperature variations. If the temperature increases, the density will decrease, and fuel volume will increase, which will give false information about the actual usable fuel within the tanks. Initially, the capacitance between the two plates will also give you the volume. However, a density compensator is placed at the bottom of the tank to correct the errors induced to fuel’s density by the temperature changes. Therefore, if you have a temperature rise and an increase in the fuel volume by 5%, the mass will remain the same as the density change will be compensated.

content.question: Which probe would be blocked for the EPR system to show a higher value and what indication pilots could check to see real thrust?

key_points: Engine Pressure Ratio (EPR) The thrust of jet engines can be controlled using the engine pressure ratio (EPR)
The ration is determined by dividing the pressure at the exhaust nozzle (turbine outlet pressure) by the pressure at the compressor entry
Both these pressures are measured by pitot tubes
learning.explanation: Engine Pressure Ratio (EPR) The thrust of jet engines can be controlled using the engine pressure ratio (EPR). The ration is determined by dividing the pressure at the exhaust nozzle (turbine outlet pressure) by the pressure at the compressor entry. Both these pressures are measured by pitot tubes. Consequently, should any of these sensors fail or the signal cannot be transferred, the indicated EPR will be different than the actual EPR. During take-off, the aircraft accelerates and the engine intake pressure will increase due to the increased forward speed. When at some point the pressure sensor on the compressor inlet becomes blocked, it cannot sense the higher intake pressure, but continues to report the low pressure at the time of blockage. The outlet pressure increases, and the sensor which is unaffected by the blockage can measure that. The turbine outlet pressure is divided by a too low compressor inlet pressure, and the result is higher than the actual EPR. During take-off, depending on the engine manufacturer, both EPR or N1 can be used for thrust setting. If EPR becomes invalid, it may be possible to continue with N1 readings.

learning.explanation: A Constant Speed Drive Unit (CSDU) is a hydraulic-mechanical unit adapting the speed of the generator to maintain a constant frequency. As the engine speed is continuously hanging, so would the output frequency, but the CSD unit alters the output torque to keep the generator running at a constant frequency. The system is connected to the engine through a dog clutch release mechanism. Whenever the CSD oil temperature is too high, oil pressure and/or level become too low, and the indicator will provide a warning in the cockpit and the pilots will be able to disconnect the CSD. content.question: In a turbine engine, what is the parameter N1, which is used to represent thrust?

options.A: N1 refers to the rotational speed of the high speed spool which consists of the high pressure compressor and the high pressure turbine.
options.B: N1 refers to the rotational speed of the low speed spool which consists of the fan, the low pressure compressor and the low pressure turbine.
options.C: the indication is usually calibrated in percent RPM.
options.D: N1 is the ratio of the turbine discharge and the compressor inlet pressure.

key_points: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow
On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR
The N1, displayed to the pilots as a percentage, is nothing else than the compressor’s first stage (the fan) rotation speed
learning.explanation: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow. On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR. The N1, displayed to the pilots as a percentage, is nothing else than the compressor’s first stage (the fan) rotation speed. In a modern gas turbine engine such as the CFM 56 fitted to the B737 or A320, the engine has two compressor turbine assemblies. Each assembly is mounted on a common shaft. The first one is a Low-Pressure compressor turbine assembly, and the second one is a High-Pressure compressor turbine assembly. The first part of the engine is the fan, which divides the incoming airflow into two streams. The first stream is directed to the next compressor stages for further compression and combustion. The rest of the airflow is accelerated around the core, providing most of the engine thrust.

learning.explanation: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow. On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR. The EPR is the ratio between the low-pressure turbine exhaust pressure (the engine’s last stage) and the engine inlet pressure (the fan’s pressure). It is a very precise parameter, so very gentle adjustments on the thrust levers must be made to achieve the desired power setting. key_points: The engine’s rotational speed (RPM) can be measured using either an electrical or an electronic tachometer
The electrical tachometer is basically a 3 phase AC tacho-generator driven by the engine
It is usually situated in the gearbox, close to the engine-driven generator
learning.explanation: The engine’s rotational speed (RPM) can be measured using either an electrical or an electronic tachometer. The electrical tachometer is basically a 3 phase AC tacho-generator driven by the engine. It is usually situated in the gearbox, close to the engine-driven generator. The current fed by the generator is fed to the indicator consisting of a synchronous motor driving a magnet-drag cup assembly that moves a pointer over a scale. The electronic tachometer is a simpler system requiring less wiring and can be fitted on any of the engine’s rotating parts. It consists of a small electromagnet probe (inductive probe) that detects the passage of a notched wheel mounted on the compressor or turbine shaft. When the notched wheel passes in front of the probe, it alters its magnetic field. The frequency at which the magnetic field of the probe is altered is directly related to the rotation speed of the compressor.

learning.explanation: The capacitance-type fuel gauging system measures the volume of fuel by measuring the capacitance of the tank which depends on the proportion of dielectrics (fuel and air) within the tanks. A compensating unit is located at the bottom of the tank in the unusable fuel area. It is always immersed in fuel so it will measure the actual capacitance of the fuel. In an engine vibration monitoring system for a turbojet, any vibration produced by the engine is amplified and filtered to remove unwanted frequencies, before being fed to the flight deck indicator

learning.explanation: The engine vibration monitoring system installed on jet engines aircraft monitors the changes in the engines’ vibration level to indicate a potential engine failure. In an engine vibration monitoring system for a turbojet, any vibration produced by the engine is amplified and filtered to remove unwanted frequencies, before being fed to the flight deck indicator. The principle of working of this filter is fairly simple. In fact, it erases any output which is normal to the engine and allows through the amplifier any frequency that is considered to be harmful to the engine and could indicate a rotor imbalance within the engine. A vibration indicator displays the vibration amplitude at a given frequency after receiving a signal from different sensors (accelerometers, magnets, piezoelectrical crystal sensors). The value indicated on the display (integrated in the EFIS) shows the level of vibration (without any value) of both N1 and N2 of either engine.

The dielectric is the solution found between the two plates of the capacitor, so in our system, they are the fuel and the air
The plates of the capacitor can hold only a certain amount of electric charge
learning.explanation: The working principle of a capacitance-type fuel gauging system is based on the variation of the capacitor’s dielectric. The dielectric is the solution found between the two plates of the capacitor, so in our system, they are the fuel and the air. The plates of the capacitor can hold only a certain amount of electric charge. This amount depends on the distance between the two plates, the area of the plates and the insulating properties of the dielectric. As you can imagine, the area of the plates and the distance between is not going to change over time, they’re fixed. So, the only variable is going to be the dielectric.

content.question: Changes in temperature of the fuel affect its density, volume and dielectric value Er. A decrease in temperature causes…

options.A: a decreases in volume, decreases in density and decreases in Er.
options.B: an increases in volume, increases in density and increases in Er.
options.C: a decreases in volume, increases in density and increases in Er.
options.D: an increases in volume, decreases in density and decreases in Er.

key_points: Capacitance type fuel quantity indicators can provide the mass of the fuel, in opposition with other fuel gauging systems that may give only the volume
The problem with the volume-based instruments is that they are subject to temperature variations
If the temperature decreases, the density will increase, and fuel volume will decrease, which will give a false indication about the actual usable fuel within the tanks
learning.explanation: Capacitance type fuel quantity indicators can provide the mass of the fuel, in opposition with other fuel gauging systems that may give only the volume. The problem with the volume-based instruments is that they are subject to temperature variations. If the temperature decreases, the density will increase, and fuel volume will decrease, which will give a false indication about the actual usable fuel within the tanks. In a capacitance system, the insulating material between the two plates is called dielectric. In this case, the dielectric is a mixing of fuel and air. In simple terms, the dielectric permittivity represents the ability of electrical charges to propagate through the dielectric. Fuel has approximately twice the capacitance of the air, but it will change as density changes. This will also influence the dielectric permittivity as an increase in density due to a lower temperature will cause an increase the dielectric permittivity.

content.question: A synchroscope is used on aeroplanes to…

options.A: reduce the vibration of each engine.
options.B: reduce the rpm of each engine.
options.C: set several engines to the same speed.
options.D: achieve optimum control of on-board voltages.

key_points: On propeller-driven multiengine aircraft, even a slight difference in RPM can create uncomfortable noise and vibrations
To reduce them, an instrument called a synchroscope is used to fine-tune the RPM of each engine so that they all operate at the same speed
One engine is identified as the master, and the others are the slaves
learning.explanation: On propeller-driven multiengine aircraft, even a slight difference in RPM can create uncomfortable noise and vibrations. To reduce them, an instrument called a synchroscope is used to fine-tune the RPM of each engine so that they all operate at the same speed. One engine is identified as the master, and the others are the slaves. The instrument indicates on a dial by means of a pointer, the variation in RPM relative to the master engine. Generally, the synchroscopes use each engine's tachometers to convert the rotational speed into an electrical current. In this way, if the slave engine is turning faster, it produces a bigger current, and the pointer will turn in a given direction. If the slave engine is rotating slower, the current provided to the synchroscope will be lower, and the pointer will turn in the opposite direction. Synchroscopes may have different operating principles; some may work based on a supplied voltage; others may compare each engine's alternators' frequencies. Modern propeller-driven multiengine airplanes have their engine RPMs automatically synchronized through various control units.
