learning.explanation: SYNCHROSCOPE Even a slight difference in RPM can create uncomfortable noise, oscillations and vibrations. The noise can be uncomfortable for the flight/cabin crew and the passengers. You can realize that engine RPMs are not synchronized during the flight if you hear a strange intermittent beat. Continuous exposure to vibrations may also induce early fatigue to the airframe. The RPM indicator only allows the pilot to set the RPM roughly, but discrepancies in engines’ speed can be hard to adjust. To overcome this problem, some aircraft are fitted with an instrument called a synchroscope. The synchroscope is an instrument that indicates whether two or more rotating devices, such as engines, are synchronized and is, therefore, used to synchronize the speeds of engines/propellers to a RPM value. In a synchroscope, one engine is identified as the master, and the others are the slaves. The instrument indicates on a dial by means of a pointer, the variation in RPM relative to the master engine. "Synchronize engine/propeller speed and synchronize fuel consumption" Incorrect. The synchroscope is used to synchronize the engines' RPM, not the fuel.

key_points: A gas turbine engine is generally providing minimal vibration

learning.explanation: A gas turbine engine is generally providing minimal vibration. Therefore, even a small increase in the level of vibration is a clear indicator of a potential impending failure. An Engine Vibration Monitoring system is fitted to detect mechanical deficiencies in the rotating parts of an engine so that corrective action is taken before greater damage occurs. content.question:
What are the advantages of an electric float gauge?
1. Ease of manufacture
2. Independence of the indication relative to the variations of the aircraft power system if the measurement is made by a ratiometer
3. Independence of the indication relative to the variations of the aircraft power system if the measurement is made by a galvanometer
4. Independence of the indication relative to temperature variations

key_points: The electrical-type quantity gauge consists of an indicator in the cockpit and a float operated transmitter installed in the tank
The transmitter sends a different level of signal to the cockpit, dependent on the height of the float in the tank, and the signal then feeds the indicator
This type of systems are simple and cheap to manufacture and some systems can be isolated from changing voltages in the aircraft electrical system
learning.explanation: The electrical-type quantity gauge consists of an indicator in the cockpit and a float operated transmitter installed in the tank. The transmitter sends a different level of signal to the cockpit, dependent on the height of the float in the tank, and the signal then feeds the indicator. This type of systems are simple and cheap to manufacture and some systems can be isolated from changing voltages in the aircraft electrical system. Other advantages of this fuel quantity gauge include: an indicator which can be located any distance from the tank; and the fuel levels of several tanks can be read on one indicator. The disadvantage of float type fuel gauges is that they are always subject to variations in temperature, measuring volume, not mass of fuel. The two primary ways of making an electric type float gauge are with a ratiometer and a wheatstone bridge (galvanometer). The ratiometer works as seen in the first figure above. The DC power is sent equally through two circuits, one circuit with a fixed resistor, and the other with a variable resistor connected to the float in the tank. Each circuit has a coil of wire on it to produce a magnetic field, and the magnetised needle sits between, pointing to a position on the dial dependent on the relative strength of the magnetic fields, which will change based on the resistance of the variable resistor (and therefore the height of the float gauge). This indication does not vary with changes in system voltage, as it is measuring relative magnetic fields from the same source (useful as aircraft system voltages vary). The wheatstone bridge (galvanometer) system, seen in the second figure above, instead measures the resistance of the same variable resistor (connected to the float) by splitting the current of the circuit between two paths, one path having 2 fixed resistors, and the other path having a fixed resistor and the variable resistor. The variable resistor then changes how the resistance is split amongst that circuit, and current will want to flow through the galvanometer in the middle either one way or the other (and by a certain amount). A galvanometer is a very precise ammeter for our purposes. This indication does vary with changes in system voltage in a linear sense (higher voltage = higher indication), so is less useful than the ratiometer.

learning.explanation: CAPACITANCE TYPE FUEL GAUGING SYSTEM The working principle of a capacitance-type fuel gauging system is based on the variation of the capacitor’s dielectric. content.question: On an twin-engine aeroplane, the synchroscope can consists of…

key_points: SYNCHROSCOPE Even a slight difference in RPM can create uncomfortable noise, oscillations and vibrations
The noise can be uncomfortable for the flight/cabin crew and the passengers
You can realize that engine RPMs are not synchronized during the flight if you hear a strange intermittent beat
learning.explanation: SYNCHROSCOPE Even a slight difference in RPM can create uncomfortable noise, oscillations and vibrations. The noise can be uncomfortable for the flight/cabin crew and the passengers. You can realize that engine RPMs are not synchronized during the flight if you hear a strange intermittent beat. Continuous exposure to vibrations may also induce early fatigue to the airframe. The RPM indicator only allows the pilot to set the RPM roughly, but discrepancies in engines’ speed can be hard to adjust. To overcome this problem, some aircraft are fitted with an instrument called a synchroscope. The synchroscope is an instrument that indicates whether two or more rotating devices, such as engines, are synchronized and is, therefore, used to synchronize the speeds of engines/propellers to an RPM value. In a synchroscope, one engine is identified as the master and it drives an alternator feeding a rotor. And the other engines are the slaves and drive their own-side alternator that is feeding a stator. The instrument indicates on a dial by means of a pointer, the variation in RPM relative to the master engine => the frequencies of the "slaves" are compared with the frequency of the "master" engine. These differences in frequency will create torque which, consequently, acts on the synchroscope indicator needle.

learning.explanation: First, it is important to understand that “electronic” ≠ “electrical”. An Electric Tachometer works on the principle of relative motion between the magnetic field and shaft of the coupled device. The motor of tachometer works as a generator, i.e. it produces the voltage based on the velocity of the shaft. An Electronic tachometer (another name for the phonic wheel and tacho probe indicator) consists of a speed probe which sends electronic impulses. These are then counted and from this information, the RPM value is derived and displayed on a servo indicator. The electrical system is capable of operation without any external power, whereas the electronic system requires a power source from the aircraft electrical supply.

learning.explanation: The electronic torquemeter consists of two coaxial shafts both fitted with a toothed gear (exciter wheel) at their end. The torque shaft is connected directly to the engine and the propeller’s gearbox. The reference shaft is connected only to the engine. The working principle is based on the phase difference measured between the two exciter wheels by an electromagnetic pick-up. Initially, the wheels are both aligned, they are in phase with each other. As soon as engine power is increased, the torque shaft will twist proportionally to the phase difference which will induce a given voltage. The electrical signal induced by the change in phase is moving a pointer indicating the value of torque on a calibrated dial.

learning.explanation: Fuel flowmeters measure the amount of fuel being delivered to the engine. The system consists of two elements: a transmitter and an indicator. The transmitter can be either volumetric or gravimetric. In the volumetric type transmitter, fuel flows through a rotor spinning at a speed determined by the fuel flow rate. This rate is sensed by an electrical pick-off that transmits the signal to an indicator in the flight deck. In the gravimetric type transmitter, the fuel flow is measured by a vane restrained by a calibrated spring, which deflects at a certain angle proportional to the mass flow. The gravimetric transmitter is compensated for density variations with temperature, by a bleed outlet. As you can imagine, the indicator of the mass flowmeter displays a mass flow straight away. However, the fuel density needs to be manually inserted in the volumetric type system to indicate a mass flow rate.

content.question: The different types of tachometers are...

key_points: Besides the electric and electronic tachometers, which are the most common, another type exists: the mechanical tachometer, mostly found on old light piston aircraft
It works on the same drag cup assembly principle as its successor, the tacho-generator
A shaft directly connected to the engine drives a permanent magnet in a drag cup
learning.explanation: Besides the electric and electronic tachometers, which are the most common, another type exists: the mechanical tachometer, mostly found on old light piston aircraft. It works on the same drag cup assembly principle as its successor, the tacho-generator. A shaft directly connected to the engine drives a permanent magnet in a drag cup. Eddy currents with their own magnetic field are generated by the rotating magnet and act on the electrons of the drag cup. The interaction between the magnetic fields produced by the Eddy currents and the magnet's magnetic field produces a turning force proportional to the rotational speed of the magnet. A small shaft connects the drag cup with a hairspring and a pointer calibrated to indicate the RPM on a dial. The main disadvantage of this system is that the shaft connecting the engine and the permanent magnet cannot be too long, usually only about 2m. Therefore, it cannot be fitted on aircraft other than light airplanes where the engine is close to the cockpit.

learning.explanation: A bourdon tube is a pressure sensing instrument designed for high-pressure systems such as oil pressure measuring. It consists of a ‘C’ shaped tube where the fluid enters through a damping choke. The other end of the tube is connected through a mechanical linkage and gears to a pointer. As fluid flows and pressure build-up, the tube will tend to unroll and move the mechanical linkage. The pressure ranges for a Bourdon tube can be vast as its movement is dependent on the metal from which it is made. For instance, a stiffer metal will be fitted for higher pressures. A bi-metal temperature compensator is also fitted at the end of the ‘C’ tube to correct for the temperature of flowing fluid, which will alter the tube’s stiffness and efficiency.

content.question: What voltage does a thermocouple produce when the temperature between its two junctions varies?

options.A: The voltage is independent of the temperature gradient.
options.B: The voltage is inversely proportional to the temperature gradient.
options.D: The voltage is directly proportional to the temperature gradient.

key_points: A thermocouple functions as a temperature sensor, producing a voltage that corresponds to the temperature disparity between its two junctions
This voltage is directly proportional to the temperature difference between the hot and cold junctions
By measuring this voltage, one can determine the temperature at the hot junction
learning.explanation: A thermocouple functions as a temperature sensor, producing a voltage that corresponds to the temperature disparity between its two junctions. This voltage is directly proportional to the temperature difference between the hot and cold junctions. By measuring this voltage, one can determine the temperature at the hot junction. The fundamental principle of thermocouples lies in the thermoelectric effect, which generates a voltage across the two junctions when a temperature difference exists between them. Thus, the correct answer is "A thermocouple generates a voltage proportional to the temperature difference between its two junctions." When one junction of two ‘dissimilar’ metals is heated a voltage proportional to the temperature between the ‘hot’ and ‘cold’ junctions occurs, and current flows in the circuit. Two commonly used metals are Copper-Constantan and Iron-Constantan, which are both able to withstand high temperatures and produce a useable voltage. To measure high temperatures up to 1000°F and above a combination of Chromel-Alumel is used. Thermocouples are used on piston engines to measure the cylinder head temperature. These systemes are also used to operate exhaust gas temperature (EGT) gauges on jet engines.

learning.explanation: The engine’s rotational speed (RPM) can be measured using either an electrical or an electronic tachometer. The electrical tachometer is basically a 3 phase AC tacho-generator driven by the engine. It is usually situated in the gearbox, close to the engine-driven generator. The current fed by the generator is fed to the indicator consisting of a synchronous motor driving a magnet-drag cup assembly that moves a pointer over a scale. The electronic tachometer is a simpler system requiring less wiring and can be fitted on any of the engine’s rotating parts. It consists of a small electromagnet probe (inductive probe) that detects the passage of a notched wheel mounted on the compressor or turbine shaft. When the notched wheel passes in front of the probe, it alters its magnetic field. The frequency at which the magnetic field of the probe is altered is directly related to the rotation speed of the compressor.

learning.explanation: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow. On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR. The N1, displayed to the pilots as a percentage, is nothing else than the compressor’s first stage rotation speed. The EPR is the ratio between the low-pressure turbine exhaust pressure (the engine’s last stage) and the engine inlet pressure (the fan’s pressure). The EGT is the temperature measured at the outlet of the turbine. It is measured by dozens of thermocouples with the hot junction mounted all around the turbine’s exhaust. The EGT is measured to monitor the engine performance and its degradation over time. When flying, if you notice that the EGT of one engine is slightly higher than the other’s one, it probably means the engine with the higher EGT is the oldest one. The N2 is the speed of the High-pressure compressor/turbine assembly. In modern commercial aircraft, this indicator is particularly useful during the engine start sequence when monitoring the start motor acceleration, the start of the fuel flow, etc.

content.question:
In a three-phase synchronous motor type tachometer:
1 – the transmitter is a direct current generator
2 – the voltage is proportional to the transmitter drive speed
3 – the frequency is proportional to the transmitter drive speed
4 – the speed indicating element is a galvanometer
5 – the speed indicating element is an asynchronous motor driving a magnetic tachometer
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: Synchronous motors consist of a stator and a rotor
The stator's field coil is excited by a 3-phase alternate current, and the rotor is a basic permanent magnet
The rotor poles will attract the opposite poles of the stator’s rotating magnetic field and will rotate at the same speed, or in other words, at synchronous speed
learning.explanation: Synchronous motors consist of a stator and a rotor. The stator's field coil is excited by a 3-phase alternate current, and the rotor is a basic permanent magnet. The rotor poles will attract the opposite poles of the stator’s rotating magnetic field and will rotate at the same speed, or in other words, at synchronous speed. If the rotor has no initial rotation force, the opposite poles’ attraction force won’t be enough to rotate the rotor and self-start the motor. In this case, a ‘squirrel cage’ will be fitted to the rotor so that it can be rotated by the electromagnetic field of the stator (supplied by 3 phase AC). When the rotor reaches its maximum speed, it will get energized and synchronized with the stator’s opposite poles to rotate at a synchronous speed. However, until the rotor becomes synchronized with the stator’s opposite poles, the squirrel cage is asynchronous. It is basically an inductive system since electricity is introduced to the rotor by magnetic induction rather than direct electric supply, and inductive systems are asynchronous by their operating principle as described above. It is believed that in this question, the examiner wants to highlight that the squirrel cage is asynchronous and the motor itself has a synchronous operation. A permanent magnet is linked through a shaft to the rotor of the synchronous motor and is rotating in an aluminum drag cup. Eddy currents with their own magnetic field are generated by the rotating magnet and act on the electrons of the drag cup. The interaction between the magnetic fields produced by the Eddy currents and the magnet's magnetic field produces a turning force that will turn the drag cup in the permanent magnet's direction. A small shaft connects the drag cup with a hairspring and a pointer calibrated to indicate the RPM on a dial. The frequency of the AC supplied to the synchronous motor is proportional to the engine’s RPM. Therefore, the higher the RPM, the higher the current supplied to the motor and also the torque resulting from the magnet rotating inside the drag-cup. The hairspring opposes the turning force to control the indication of the pointer.

content.question: Concerning the thrust measurement, the N1 is defined as the…

key_points: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow
On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR
The N1, displayed to the pilots as a percentage, is nothing else than the compressor’s first stage (the fan) rotation speed
learning.explanation: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow. On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR. The N1, displayed to the pilots as a percentage, is nothing else than the compressor’s first stage (the fan) rotation speed. In a modern gas turbine engine such as the CFM 56 fitted to the B737 or A320, the engine has two compressor turbine assemblies. Each assembly is mounted on a common shaft. The first one is a Low Pressure compressor turbine assembly, and the second one is the High Pressure compressor turbine assembly. The first part of the engine is the fan, which divides the incoming airflow into two streams. The first stream is directed to the next compressor stages for further compression and combustion. The rest of the airflow is accelerated around the core, providing most of the engine thrust. Be careful! The wording of the question is very misleading. You need to remember what a compressor stage is. One stage in a compressor consists of a rotating disk of rotor blades followed by the stator's stationary blades. Usually, manufacturers refer to the first stage of the LP compressor as the bypass fan (see the attached picture of the PW-1000 G engine). We agree that both ‘first stage compressor speed’ and ‘low pressure shaft speed’ are correct answers as the fan is technically the first stage of the LP compressor. However, the examiner most probably wants to point-out the difference between the fan and the next stages of the LP compressor as it has a slightly different function than the rest of the LP compressor stages (division of the airflow into two different streams). Therefore, the whole scope of the provided correct answer is to stress that the N1 is defined as the fan’s speed. Note: This is the correct answer indicated by EASA at the official instrumentation exam according to other students’ feedback. Please, don’t hesitate to send us your feedback if you get this question at your official exam so that we can update the wording and/or edit the explanation accordingly.

In fact, the level of vibration is usually very low in a gas turbine engine. Therefore even slight out-of-balance conditions can be detected. Small, unusual vibrations need to be monitored and investigated as soon as possible. An engine consists of thousands of different sensitive parts subject to very high-stress levels. Therefore, early fatigue and cracking can be caused by abnormal vibrations.

The EPR is the ratio between the turbine discharge pressure (measured at the low-pressure turbine exhaust, which is the last stage of the engine) and the compressor inlet pressure (measured at the engine’s inlet, usually the first or second stage)
learning.explanation: Some engines use the Engine Pressure Ratio (EPR) to control the thrust setting. The EPR is the ratio between the turbine discharge pressure (measured at the low-pressure turbine exhaust, which is the last stage of the engine) and the compressor inlet pressure (measured at the engine’s inlet, usually the first or second stage).

content.question: During take-off, the front probe of an EPR system becomes blocked by ingested debris or icing but the rear probe remains unaffected. The displayed EPR will likely be…

options.A: equal to zero, and N1 should be used instead.
options.B: lower than the actual EPR value.
options.C: higher than the actual EPR value.
options.D: equal to the LP turbine exhaust pressure.

key_points: Engine Pressure Ratio (EPR) The thrust of jet engines can be controlled using the engine pressure ratio (EPR)
The ration is determined by dividing the pressure at the exhaust nozzle (turbine outlet pressure) by the pressure at the compressor entry
Both these pressures are measured by pitot tubes
learning.explanation: Engine Pressure Ratio (EPR) The thrust of jet engines can be controlled using the engine pressure ratio (EPR). The ration is determined by dividing the pressure at the exhaust nozzle (turbine outlet pressure) by the pressure at the compressor entry. Both these pressures are measured by pitot tubes. Consequently, should any of these sensors fail or the signal cannot be transferred, the indicated EPR will be different than the actual EPR. During take-off, the aircraft accelerates and the engine intake pressure will increase due to the increased forward speed. When at some point the pressure sensor on the compressor inlet becomes blocked, it cannot sense the higher intake pressure, but continues to report the low pressure at the time of blockage. The outlet pressure increases, and the sensor which is unaffected by the blockage can measure that. The turbine outlet pressure is divided by a too low compressor inlet pressure, and the result is higher than the actual EPR.

content.question: For a capacitance type fuel indication system, what indication would you expect in case of failure?

options.A: A sudden full deflection of the fuel gauge towards empty.
options.B: A progressive deflection of the gauge to full.
options.D: A red flag in the gauge.

key_points: CAPACITANCE TYPE FUEL GAUGING SYSTEM The working principle of a capacitance-type fuel gauging system is based on the variation of the capacitor’s dielectric
The dielectric is the solution found between the two plates of the capacitor, so in our system, they are the fuel and the air
The plates of the capacitor can hold only a certain amount of electric charge
learning.explanation: CAPACITANCE TYPE FUEL GAUGING SYSTEM The working principle of a capacitance-type fuel gauging system is based on the variation of the capacitor’s dielectric. The dielectric is the solution found between the two plates of the capacitor, so in our system, they are the fuel and the air. The plates of the capacitor can hold only a certain amount of electric charge. This amount depends on the distance between the two plates, the area of the plates and the insulating properties of the dielectric. In contrast to a float system, capacitance type fuel gauges measure fuel mass, which is directly proportional to the contained amount of energy. In case of a malfunction, the capacitance would reduce to zero, causing the fuel gauge to indicate “empty”.

content.question:
The different types of tachometer are:
1 – electrical
2 – mechanical
3 – electronic
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: There are 3 types of tachometers currently in use: the electrical, electronic, and mechanical tachometer
The electrical tachometer is basically a 3 phase AC tacho-generator driven by the engine
It is usually situated in the gearbox, close to the engine-driven generator
learning.explanation: There are 3 types of tachometers currently in use: the electrical, electronic, and mechanical tachometer. The electrical tachometer is basically a 3 phase AC tacho-generator driven by the engine. It is usually situated in the gearbox, close to the engine-driven generator. The current fed by the generator is fed to the indicator consisting of a synchronous motor driving a magnet-drag cup assembly that moves a pointer over a scale. The electronic tachometer is a simpler system requiring less wiring and can be fitted on any of the engine’s rotating parts. It consists of a small electromagnet probe (inductive probe) that detects the passage of a notched wheel mounted on the compressor or turbine shaft. When the notched wheel passes in front of the probe, it alters its magnetic field. The frequency at which the magnetic field of the probe is altered is directly related to the rotation speed of the compressor. The mechanical tachometer works on the same drag cup assembly principle as its successor, the tacho-generator. A shaft directly connected to the engine drives a permanent magnet in a drag cup. The main disadvantage of this system is that the shaft connecting the engine and the permanent magnet cannot be too long, usually only about 2m. Therefore, it cannot be fitted on aircraft other than light airplanes where the engine is close to the cockpit.

learning.explanation: Reduce Structural vibration and noise – CORRECT. On propeller-driven multiengine aircraft, even a slight difference in RPM can create uncomfortable noise and vibrations. The noise can be uncomfortable for the flight/cabin crew and the passengers. Continuous exposure to vibrations may induce early fatigue to the airframe. Achieve symmetrical thrust and fuel consumption – INCORRECT. This statement is a bit unclear as technically if you synchronize your engine RPMs, they will provide symmetrical thrust and the fuel consumption on both engines (or more) is going to be the same. However, the synchroscope is used to synchronize the engines, not the fuel.

content.question: The basic principle of a capacitance fuel gauge system is that the…

options.B: electromotive force of a capacitor depends on the nature of the dielectric in which it is immersed.
options.C: capacitance of a capacitor only depends on the density of the liquid on which it is immersed.
options.D: internal resistance of a capacitor depends on the nature of the dielectric in which it is immersed.

key_points: A capacitor consists of two electrically charged plates of the same size, located at a fixed distance from each other
Fuel and air are the dielectrics, so the capacitance between the two plates varies depending on the amount of fuel and air found between the plates

Capacitance is based on the following formula: Capacitance = E x A/D E = dielectric permittivity D = distance between capacitor’s plates A = area of the plates As you can see, only one of these items is variable: the dielectric permittivity
learning.explanation: A capacitor consists of two electrically charged plates of the same size, located at a fixed distance from each other. Fuel and air are the dielectrics, so the capacitance between the two plates varies depending on the amount of fuel and air found between the plates. Capacitance is based on the following formula: Capacitance = E x A/D E = dielectric permittivity D = distance between capacitor’s plates A = area of the plates As you can see, only one of these items is variable: the dielectric permittivity. To put it simple, the dielectric permittivity is a parameter that measures how well an electric field will interact with any given material. Fuel has approximately twice the capacitance of the air, so the current sensed between the capacitor’s plates is going to be proportional to the level of fuel in the tanks.

content.question:
Given:
P = power.
T = torque. n = RPM.
The correct relationship is…

key_points: Power is work done per unit of time
Work is generated when a force is applied to an object and moves it over a certain distance
It is measured in Joules, and 1 Joule = 1 Nm (same unit as torque)
learning.explanation: Power is work done per unit of time. Work is generated when a force is applied to an object and moves it over a certain distance. It is measured in Joules, and 1 Joule = 1 Nm (same unit as torque). The Rotations Per Minute (rpm) define an angular motion over time. Therefore, the product of work generated by a body (Nm) in angular motion over time gives you the power produced by that body. Try to remember the correct formula by using the units of each variable. P = T x n → n = P / T Where: T – torque in Nm N – rotations per minute (1/min) P – Power in Watt (W) Since 1 W = 1 Nm/s, a small conversion needs to be made from rpm (1/min) to rps (1/sec) by using: rpm ÷ 60 = rps

content.question:
Consider two twin-engined, propeller-driven aeroplanes. The propellers on AP1 rotate clockwise, and those on AP2 rotate anticlockwise.
If there's a left engine failure in both aeroplanes, which will give the largest yawing moment, and from which side will it be?

options.A: Aircraft with AP1 produces greater yaw to the left
options.B: Aircraft with AP1 produces greater yaw to the right
options.C: Aircraft with AP2 produces greater yaw to the left
options.D: Aircraft with AP2 produces greater yaw to the right

key_points: When an engine fails on a multi-engine aircraft, there will be a decrease in thrust and an increase in drag on the side of the failed engine
Primarily there will be a yawing moment towards the failed (dead) engine
The critical engine is the engine which would give the biggest yawing moment if it fails
learning.explanation: When an engine fails on a multi-engine aircraft, there will be a decrease in thrust and an increase in drag on the side of the failed engine. Primarily there will be a yawing moment towards the failed (dead) engine. The critical engine is the engine which would give the biggest yawing moment if it fails. One of the factors influencing the yawing moment following an engine failure on a multi-engine aircraft is the length of the thrust arm (i.e., distance from the aircraft's CG to the thrust line of the operating engine). In case of a propeller engine aircraft, the length of the thrust arm is determined by the asymmetric effect of the propeller. When the aircraft is flying with a positive angle of attack (which is normal), the thrust line of a clockwise rotating propeller (when viewed from the rear) is displaced to the right of the engine centre line. This is because the down-going blade generates more thrust than the up-going blade (P-factor). If both engines rotate clockwise, the starboard (right) engine will have a longer thrust arm than the port (left) engine. If the left engine fails, the thrust of the right engine acts through a longer thrust arm and will give a larger yawing moment. If both engines rotate inward, they will have the same (shorter) thrust arm (counter-rotating propellers). Of course, no matter the direction of the propellers, a failure of the left engine will always produce a yaw to the left, it is just bigger if the aircraft has clockwise rotation propellers. If you find this question in your INSTRUMENTATION exam, you should appeal.

content.question: On an twin-engine aeroplane, the synchroscope uses the following principle…

options.A: it mathematically subtracts the vibrations of both engines.
options.B: a piezoelectric sensor measures the vibrations on each engine.
options.C: it measures the frequency difference between the two engine driven alternators.
options.D: it mathematically subtracts the RPM of both engines.

key_points: Synchroscopes may have different operating principles; some may work based on a supplied voltage; others may compare each engine's alternators' frequencies
Modern propeller-driven multiengine airplanes have their engine RPMs automatically synchronized through various control units
In a synchroscope, one engine is identified as the master, and the others are the slaves
learning.explanation: Synchroscopes may have different operating principles; some may work based on a supplied voltage; others may compare each engine's alternators' frequencies. Modern propeller-driven multiengine airplanes have their engine RPMs automatically synchronized through various control units. In a synchroscope, one engine is identified as the master, and the others are the slaves. The instrument indicates on a dial using a pointer the variation in RPM relative to the master engine. Generally, the synchroscopes use each engine's tachometers to convert the rotational speed into an electrical current. In this way, if the slave engine is turning faster, it produces a bigger current, and the pointer will turn in a given direction. If the slave engine is rotating slower, the current provided to the synchroscope will be lower, and the pointer will turn in the opposite direction.

content.question: A capacitance-type quantity measurement system is based on the variation of:

options.A: the plate surface of a capacitor.

key_points: The working principle of a capacitance-type fuel gauging system is based on the variation of the capacitor’s dielectric
The dielectric is the solution found between the two plates of the capacitor, so in our system, they are the fuel and the air
The plates of the capacitor can hold only a certain amount of electric charge
learning.explanation: The working principle of a capacitance-type fuel gauging system is based on the variation of the capacitor’s dielectric. The dielectric is the solution found between the two plates of the capacitor, so in our system, they are the fuel and the air. The plates of the capacitor can hold only a certain amount of electric charge. This amount depends on the distance between the two plates, the area of the plates and the insulating properties of the dielectric. As you can imagine, the area of the plates and the distance between is not going to change over time, they’re fixed. So, the only variable is going to be the dielectric. content.question:
The indication of a fuel float gauge varies with:
1 – pitch angle
2 – accelerations
3 – fuel temperature
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: The float-type fuel gauging system consists of a simple mechanical float sitting on the fuel level, linked via a mechanical arm to a gauge indicating the volume
One of the main limitations of the volume indicating systems is that temperature variations will impact the reading of the tanks’ actual fuel quantity
In fact, at warm temperatures, fuel is heated up and expands
learning.explanation: The float-type fuel gauging system consists of a simple mechanical float sitting on the fuel level, linked via a mechanical arm to a gauge indicating the volume. One of the main limitations of the volume indicating systems is that temperature variations will impact the reading of the tanks’ actual fuel quantity. In fact, at warm temperatures, fuel is heated up and expands. Since the volume of fuel is increasing, the float-type gauge indicates an increase of fuel quantity within the tanks. The reading will also be imprecise during maneuvers (pitch angle changes), accelerations, and turbulence; the reading will only be reliable in straight and level flight. To overcome this problem, modern capacitor-type fuel gauging systems are fitted with a density compensating unit, which accounts for the temperature changes by converting the output from volume to mass of fuel.

content.question: In a compensated capacitance type quantity indicating system, the contents gauge of a half-full fuel tank indicates a fuel mass of 8000 kg. If a temperature rise increased the volume of fuel by 5%, the indicated fuel mass would…

key_points: Capacitance type fuel quantity indicators can provide the fuel's mass, in opposition with other fuel gauging systems that may give only the volume
The problem with the volume-based instrument is that it is subject to temperature variations
If the temperature increases, the density will decrease, and fuel volume will increase, which will give false information about the actual usable fuel within the tanks
learning.explanation: Capacitance type fuel quantity indicators can provide the fuel's mass, in opposition with other fuel gauging systems that may give only the volume. The problem with the volume-based instrument is that it is subject to temperature variations. If the temperature increases, the density will decrease, and fuel volume will increase, which will give false information about the actual usable fuel within the tanks. Initially, the capacitance between the two plates will also give you the volume. However, a density compensator is placed at the bottom of the tank to correct the errors induced to fuel’s density by the temperature changes. Therefore, if you have a temperature rise and an increase in the fuel volume by 5%, the mass will remain the same as the density change will be compensated.

content.question: Which probe would be blocked for the EPR system to show a higher value and what indication pilots could check to see real thrust?

key_points: Engine Pressure Ratio (EPR) The thrust of jet engines can be controlled using the engine pressure ratio (EPR)
The ration is determined by dividing the pressure at the exhaust nozzle (turbine outlet pressure) by the pressure at the compressor entry
Both these pressures are measured by pitot tubes
learning.explanation: Engine Pressure Ratio (EPR) The thrust of jet engines can be controlled using the engine pressure ratio (EPR). The ration is determined by dividing the pressure at the exhaust nozzle (turbine outlet pressure) by the pressure at the compressor entry. Both these pressures are measured by pitot tubes. Consequently, should any of these sensors fail or the signal cannot be transferred, the indicated EPR will be different than the actual EPR. During take-off, the aircraft accelerates and the engine intake pressure will increase due to the increased forward speed. When at some point the pressure sensor on the compressor inlet becomes blocked, it cannot sense the higher intake pressure, but continues to report the low pressure at the time of blockage. The outlet pressure increases, and the sensor which is unaffected by the blockage can measure that. The turbine outlet pressure is divided by a too low compressor inlet pressure, and the result is higher than the actual EPR. During take-off, depending on the engine manufacturer, both EPR or N1 can be used for thrust setting. If EPR becomes invalid, it may be possible to continue with N1 readings.

learning.explanation: A Constant Speed Drive Unit (CSDU) is a hydraulic-mechanical unit adapting the speed of the generator to maintain a constant frequency. As the engine speed is continuously hanging, so would the output frequency, but the CSD unit alters the output torque to keep the generator running at a constant frequency. The system is connected to the engine through a dog clutch release mechanism. Whenever the CSD oil temperature is too high, oil pressure and/or level become too low, and the indicator will provide a warning in the cockpit and the pilots will be able to disconnect the CSD. After disconnection, the CSD unit can only be reconnected on the ground by the engineers.

options.A: N1 refers to the rotational speed of the high speed spool which consists of the high pressure compressor and the high pressure turbine.
options.B: N1 refers to the rotational speed of the low speed spool which consists of the fan, the low pressure compressor and the low pressure turbine.
options.C: the indication is usually calibrated in percent RPM.
options.D: N1 is the ratio of the turbine discharge and the compressor inlet pressure.

key_points: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow
On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR
The N1, displayed to the pilots as a percentage, is nothing else than the compressor’s first stage (the fan) rotation speed
learning.explanation: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow. On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR. The N1, displayed to the pilots as a percentage, is nothing else than the compressor’s first stage (the fan) rotation speed. In a modern gas turbine engine such as the CFM 56 fitted to the B737 or A320, the engine has two compressor turbine assemblies. Each assembly is mounted on a common shaft. The first one is a Low-Pressure compressor turbine assembly, and the second one is a High-Pressure compressor turbine assembly. The first part of the engine is the fan, which divides the incoming airflow into two streams. The first stream is directed to the next compressor stages for further compression and combustion. The rest of the airflow is accelerated around the core, providing most of the engine thrust.

learning.explanation: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow. On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR. The EPR is the ratio between the low-pressure turbine exhaust pressure (the engine’s last stage) and the engine inlet pressure (the fan’s pressure). key_points: The engine’s rotational speed (RPM) can be measured using either an electrical or an electronic tachometer
The electrical tachometer is basically a 3 phase AC tacho-generator driven by the engine
It is usually situated in the gearbox, close to the engine-driven generator
learning.explanation: The engine’s rotational speed (RPM) can be measured using either an electrical or an electronic tachometer. The electrical tachometer is basically a 3 phase AC tacho-generator driven by the engine. It is usually situated in the gearbox, close to the engine-driven generator. The current fed by the generator is fed to the indicator consisting of a synchronous motor driving a magnet-drag cup assembly that moves a pointer over a scale. The electronic tachometer is a simpler system requiring less wiring and can be fitted on any of the engine’s rotating parts. It consists of a small electromagnet probe (inductive probe) that detects the passage of a notched wheel mounted on the compressor or turbine shaft. When the notched wheel passes in front of the probe, it alters its magnetic field. The frequency at which the magnetic field of the probe is altered is directly related to the rotation speed of the compressor.

learning.explanation: The engine vibration monitoring system installed on jet engines aircraft monitors the changes in the engines’ vibration level to indicate a potential engine failure. In an engine vibration monitoring system for a turbojet, any vibration produced by the engine is amplified and filtered to remove unwanted frequencies, before being fed to the flight deck indicator. The principle of working of this filter is fairly simple. In fact, it erases any output which is normal to the engine and allows through the amplifier any frequency that is considered to be harmful to the engine and could indicate a rotor imbalance within the engine. A vibration indicator displays the vibration amplitude at a given frequency after receiving a signal from different sensors (accelerometers, magnets, piezoelectrical crystal sensors). The plates of the capacitor can hold only a certain amount of electric charge
learning.explanation: The working principle of a capacitance-type fuel gauging system is based on the variation of the capacitor’s dielectric. The dielectric is the solution found between the two plates of the capacitor, so in our system, they are the fuel and the air. The plates of the capacitor can hold only a certain amount of electric charge. This amount depends on the distance between the two plates, the area of the plates and the insulating properties of the dielectric. options.C: a decreases in volume, increases in density and increases in Er.
options.D: an increases in volume, decreases in density and decreases in Er.

key_points: Capacitance type fuel quantity indicators can provide the mass of the fuel, in opposition with other fuel gauging systems that may give only the volume
The problem with the volume-based instruments is that they are subject to temperature variations
If the temperature decreases, the density will increase, and fuel volume will decrease, which will give a false indication about the actual usable fuel within the tanks
learning.explanation: Capacitance type fuel quantity indicators can provide the mass of the fuel, in opposition with other fuel gauging systems that may give only the volume. The problem with the volume-based instruments is that they are subject to temperature variations. If the temperature decreases, the density will increase, and fuel volume will decrease, which will give a false indication about the actual usable fuel within the tanks. In a capacitance system, the insulating material between the two plates is called dielectric. In this case, the dielectric is a mixing of fuel and air. In simple terms, the dielectric permittivity represents the ability of electrical charges to propagate through the dielectric. Fuel has approximately twice the capacitance of the air, but it will change as density changes. This will also influence the dielectric permittivity as an increase in density due to a lower temperature will cause an increase the dielectric permittivity.

content.question: A synchroscope is used on aeroplanes to…

options.A: reduce the vibration of each engine.
options.B: reduce the rpm of each engine.
options.C: set several engines to the same speed.
options.D: achieve optimum control of on-board voltages.

key_points: On propeller-driven multiengine aircraft, even a slight difference in RPM can create uncomfortable noise and vibrations
To reduce them, an instrument called a synchroscope is used to fine-tune the RPM of each engine so that they all operate at the same speed
One engine is identified as the master, and the others are the slaves
learning.explanation: On propeller-driven multiengine aircraft, even a slight difference in RPM can create uncomfortable noise and vibrations. To reduce them, an instrument called a synchroscope is used to fine-tune the RPM of each engine so that they all operate at the same speed. One engine is identified as the master, and the others are the slaves. The instrument indicates on a dial by means of a pointer, the variation in RPM relative to the master engine. Generally, the synchroscopes use each engine's tachometers to convert the rotational speed into an electrical current. In this way, if the slave engine is turning faster, it produces a bigger current, and the pointer will turn in a given direction. If the slave engine is rotating slower, the current provided to the synchroscope will be lower, and the pointer will turn in the opposite direction. Synchroscopes may have different operating principles; some may work based on a supplied voltage; others may compare each engine's alternators' frequencies. Modern propeller-driven multiengine airplanes have their engine RPMs automatically synchronized through various control units.

learning.explanation: SYNCHROSCOPE Even a slight difference in RPM can create uncomfortable noise, oscillations and vibrations. The noise can be uncomfortable for the flight/cabin crew and the passengers. You can realize that engine RPMs are not synchronized during the flight if you hear a strange intermittent beat. Continuous exposure to vibrations may also induce early fatigue to the airframe. The RPM indicator only allows the pilot to set the RPM roughly, but discrepancies in engines’ speed can be hard to adjust. To overcome this problem, some aircraft are fitted with an instrument called a synchroscope. The synchroscope is an instrument that indicates whether two or more rotating devices, such as engines, are synchronized and is, therefore, used to synchronize the speeds of engines/propellers to a RPM value. In a synchroscope, one engine is identified as the master, and the others are the slaves. The instrument indicates on a dial by means of a pointer, the variation in RPM relative to the master engine. "Synchronize engine/propeller speed and synchronize fuel consumption" Incorrect. The synchroscope is used to synchronize the engines' RPM, not the fuel.

key_points: A gas turbine engine is generally providing minimal vibration

learning.explanation: A gas turbine engine is generally providing minimal vibration. Therefore, even a small increase in the level of vibration is a clear indicator of a potential impending failure. An Engine Vibration Monitoring system is fitted to detect mechanical deficiencies in the rotating parts of an engine so that corrective action is taken before greater damage occurs. The vibration monitoring unit measures the radial and transverse vibrations using accelerometers operating on the piezo-electric principle. The frequencies of the detected vibrations will be filtered so that only those indicating a potential malfunction are considered, the normal engine frequencies are erased as they’re not relevant to indicate hazardous vibrations. The vibration indicator will be either a graduated scale with a pointer or a digital display, showing a value without any unit.

content.question:
What are the advantages of an electric float gauge?
1. Ease of manufacture
2. Independence of the indication relative to the variations of the aircraft power system if the measurement is made by a ratiometer
3. Independence of the indication relative to the variations of the aircraft power system if the measurement is made by a galvanometer

key_points: The electrical-type quantity gauge consists of an indicator in the cockpit and a float operated transmitter installed in the tank
The transmitter sends a different level of signal to the cockpit, dependent on the height of the float in the tank, and the signal then feeds the indicator
This type of systems are simple and cheap to manufacture and some systems can be isolated from changing voltages in the aircraft electrical system
learning.explanation: The electrical-type quantity gauge consists of an indicator in the cockpit and a float operated transmitter installed in the tank. The transmitter sends a different level of signal to the cockpit, dependent on the height of the float in the tank, and the signal then feeds the indicator. This type of systems are simple and cheap to manufacture and some systems can be isolated from changing voltages in the aircraft electrical system. Other advantages of this fuel quantity gauge include: an indicator which can be located any distance from the tank; and the fuel levels of several tanks can be read on one indicator. The disadvantage of float type fuel gauges is that they are always subject to variations in temperature, measuring volume, not mass of fuel. The two primary ways of making an electric type float gauge are with a ratiometer and a wheatstone bridge (galvanometer). The ratiometer works as seen in the first figure above. The DC power is sent equally through two circuits, one circuit with a fixed resistor, and the other with a variable resistor connected to the float in the tank. Each circuit has a coil of wire on it to produce a magnetic field, and the magnetised needle sits between, pointing to a position on the dial dependent on the relative strength of the magnetic fields, which will change based on the resistance of the variable resistor (and therefore the height of the float gauge). This indication does not vary with changes in system voltage, as it is measuring relative magnetic fields from the same source (useful as aircraft system voltages vary). The wheatstone bridge (galvanometer) system, seen in the second figure above, instead measures the resistance of the same variable resistor (connected to the float) by splitting the current of the circuit between two paths, one path having 2 fixed resistors, and the other path having a fixed resistor and the variable resistor. The variable resistor then changes how the resistance is split amongst that circuit, and current will want to flow through the galvanometer in the middle either one way or the other (and by a certain amount). A galvanometer is a very precise ammeter for our purposes. This indication does vary with changes in system voltage in a linear sense (higher voltage = higher indication), so is less useful than the ratiometer.

learning.explanation: CAPACITANCE TYPE FUEL GAUGING SYSTEM The working principle of a capacitance-type fuel gauging system is based on the variation of the capacitor’s dielectric. The dielectric is the solution found between the two plates of the capacitor, so in our system, they are the fuel and the air. The plates of the capacitor can hold only a certain amount of electric charge. This amount depends on the distance between the two plates, the area of the plates and the insulating properties of the dielectric. content.question: On an twin-engine aeroplane, the synchroscope can consists of…

key_points: SYNCHROSCOPE Even a slight difference in RPM can create uncomfortable noise, oscillations and vibrations
The noise can be uncomfortable for the flight/cabin crew and the passengers
You can realize that engine RPMs are not synchronized during the flight if you hear a strange intermittent beat
learning.explanation: SYNCHROSCOPE Even a slight difference in RPM can create uncomfortable noise, oscillations and vibrations. The noise can be uncomfortable for the flight/cabin crew and the passengers. You can realize that engine RPMs are not synchronized during the flight if you hear a strange intermittent beat. Continuous exposure to vibrations may also induce early fatigue to the airframe. The RPM indicator only allows the pilot to set the RPM roughly, but discrepancies in engines’ speed can be hard to adjust. To overcome this problem, some aircraft are fitted with an instrument called a synchroscope. The synchroscope is an instrument that indicates whether two or more rotating devices, such as engines, are synchronized and is, therefore, used to synchronize the speeds of engines/propellers to an RPM value. In a synchroscope, one engine is identified as the master and it drives an alternator feeding a rotor. And the other engines are the slaves and drive their own-side alternator that is feeding a stator. The instrument indicates on a dial by means of a pointer, the variation in RPM relative to the master engine => the frequencies of the "slaves" are compared with the frequency of the "master" engine. These differences in frequency will create torque which, consequently, acts on the synchroscope indicator needle.

learning.explanation: First, it is important to understand that “electronic” ≠ “electrical”. An Electric Tachometer works on the principle of relative motion between the magnetic field and shaft of the coupled device. The motor of tachometer works as a generator, i.e. it produces the voltage based on the velocity of the shaft. An Electronic tachometer (another name for the phonic wheel and tacho probe indicator) consists of a speed probe which sends electronic impulses. These are then counted and from this information, the RPM value is derived and displayed on a servo indicator. The electrical system is capable of operation without any external power, whereas the electronic system requires a power source from the aircraft electrical supply.

The torque shaft is connected directly to the engine and the propeller’s gearbox

learning.explanation: The electronic torquemeter consists of two coaxial shafts both fitted with a toothed gear (exciter wheel) at their end. The torque shaft is connected directly to the engine and the propeller’s gearbox. The reference shaft is connected only to the engine. The working principle is based on the phase difference measured between the two exciter wheels by an electromagnetic pick-up. Initially, the wheels are both aligned, they are in phase with each other. As soon as engine power is increased, the torque shaft will twist proportionally to the phase difference which will induce a given voltage. The electrical signal induced by the change in phase is moving a pointer indicating the value of torque on a calibrated dial.

learning.explanation: Fuel flowmeters measure the amount of fuel being delivered to the engine. The system consists of two elements: a transmitter and an indicator. The transmitter can be either volumetric or gravimetric. In the volumetric type transmitter, fuel flows through a rotor spinning at a speed determined by the fuel flow rate. This rate is sensed by an electrical pick-off that transmits the signal to an indicator in the flight deck. In the gravimetric type transmitter, the fuel flow is measured by a vane restrained by a calibrated spring, which deflects at a certain angle proportional to the mass flow. The gravimetric transmitter is compensated for density variations with temperature, by a bleed outlet. As you can imagine, the indicator of the mass flowmeter displays a mass flow straight away. However, the fuel density needs to be manually inserted in the volumetric type system to indicate a mass flow rate.

key_points: Besides the electric and electronic tachometers, which are the most common, another type exists: the mechanical tachometer, mostly found on old light piston aircraft
It works on the same drag cup assembly principle as its successor, the tacho-generator
A shaft directly connected to the engine drives a permanent magnet in a drag cup
learning.explanation: Besides the electric and electronic tachometers, which are the most common, another type exists: the mechanical tachometer, mostly found on old light piston aircraft. It works on the same drag cup assembly principle as its successor, the tacho-generator. A shaft directly connected to the engine drives a permanent magnet in a drag cup. Eddy currents with their own magnetic field are generated by the rotating magnet and act on the electrons of the drag cup. The interaction between the magnetic fields produced by the Eddy currents and the magnet's magnetic field produces a turning force proportional to the rotational speed of the magnet. A small shaft connects the drag cup with a hairspring and a pointer calibrated to indicate the RPM on a dial. The main disadvantage of this system is that the shaft connecting the engine and the permanent magnet cannot be too long, usually only about 2m. Therefore, it cannot be fitted on aircraft other than light airplanes where the engine is close to the cockpit.

learning.explanation: A bourdon tube is a pressure sensing instrument designed for high-pressure systems such as oil pressure measuring. It consists of a ‘C’ shaped tube where the fluid enters through a damping choke. The other end of the tube is connected through a mechanical linkage and gears to a pointer. As fluid flows and pressure build-up, the tube will tend to unroll and move the mechanical linkage. The pressure ranges for a Bourdon tube can be vast as its movement is dependent on the metal from which it is made. For instance, a stiffer metal will be fitted for higher pressures. A bi-metal temperature compensator is also fitted at the end of the ‘C’ tube to correct for the temperature of flowing fluid, which will alter the tube’s stiffness and efficiency.

content.question: What voltage does a thermocouple produce when the temperature between its two junctions varies?

options.A: The voltage is independent of the temperature gradient.
options.B: The voltage is inversely proportional to the temperature gradient.
options.D: The voltage is directly proportional to the temperature gradient.

key_points: A thermocouple functions as a temperature sensor, producing a voltage that corresponds to the temperature disparity between its two junctions
This voltage is directly proportional to the temperature difference between the hot and cold junctions
By measuring this voltage, one can determine the temperature at the hot junction
learning.explanation: A thermocouple functions as a temperature sensor, producing a voltage that corresponds to the temperature disparity between its two junctions. This voltage is directly proportional to the temperature difference between the hot and cold junctions. By measuring this voltage, one can determine the temperature at the hot junction. The fundamental principle of thermocouples lies in the thermoelectric effect, which generates a voltage across the two junctions when a temperature difference exists between them. Thus, the correct answer is "A thermocouple generates a voltage proportional to the temperature difference between its two junctions." When one junction of two ‘dissimilar’ metals is heated a voltage proportional to the temperature between the ‘hot’ and ‘cold’ junctions occurs, and current flows in the circuit. Two commonly used metals are Copper-Constantan and Iron-Constantan, which are both able to withstand high temperatures and produce a useable voltage. To measure high temperatures up to 1000°F and above a combination of Chromel-Alumel is used. Thermocouples are used on piston engines to measure the cylinder head temperature. These systemes are also used to operate exhaust gas temperature (EGT) gauges on jet engines.

learning.explanation: The engine’s rotational speed (RPM) can be measured using either an electrical or an electronic tachometer. The electrical tachometer is basically a 3 phase AC tacho-generator driven by the engine. It is usually situated in the gearbox, close to the engine-driven generator. The current fed by the generator is fed to the indicator consisting of a synchronous motor driving a magnet-drag cup assembly that moves a pointer over a scale. The electronic tachometer is a simpler system requiring less wiring and can be fitted on any of the engine’s rotating parts. It consists of a small electromagnet probe (inductive probe) that detects the passage of a notched wheel mounted on the compressor or turbine shaft. When the notched wheel passes in front of the probe, it alters its magnetic field. The frequency at which the magnetic field of the probe is altered is directly related to the rotation speed of the compressor.

content.question:
The parameters used to represent thrust are:

2 – N2 (high pressure shaft speed)

The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow
On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR
The N1, displayed to the pilots as a percentage, is nothing else than the compressor’s first stage rotation speed
learning.explanation: A jet engine is different from a conventional piston engine, as thrust is the direct force output from the engines and is roughly proportional to the fuel flow. On modern commercial jets, the primary source of information regarding the engine’s power is the N1 and the EPR. The N1, displayed to the pilots as a percentage, is nothing else than the compressor’s first stage rotation speed. The EPR is the ratio between the low-pressure turbine exhaust pressure (the engine’s last stage) and the engine inlet pressure (the fan’s pressure). The EGT is the temperature measured at the outlet of the turbine. It is measured by dozens of thermocouples with the hot junction mounted all around the turbine’s exhaust. The EGT is measured to monitor the engine performance and its degradation over time. When flying, if you notice that the EGT of one engine is slightly higher than the other’s one, it probably means the engine with the higher EGT is the oldest one. The N2 is the speed of the High-pressure compressor/turbine assembly. In modern commercial aircraft, this indicator is particularly useful during the engine start sequence when monitoring the start motor acceleration, the start of the fuel flow, etc.

Fuel has approximately twice the capacitance of the air, but it will change as density changes. This will also influence the dielectric permittivity as a decrease in density will cause a decrease in the dielectric permittivity.

learning.explanation: The Newton (N) is the SI unit for force, and the meter (m) is the SI unit to measure a length. The product between a force and a length is called the Newton-meter (N m) and is used to measure the torque. The torque, also called the moment, is the force that will cause an object to rotate about an axis. Therefore, 1 Nm of torque represents a force of 1 N applied to an object which is 1 m long: Torque = Force (F) x lever arm (m)

learning.explanation: On multi-engine aircraft, to reduce structural vibration and noise the speed of all engines must be synchronized. It is impractical to have the pilot adjust the throttle of each engine manually to synchronize the speed, and individual indicators may vary in accuracy. In order to facilitate manual adjustment of speed an additional instrument known as a Synchroscope is used. The instrument provides a qualitative indication of the difference in speeds between two or more engines. One engine is selected as a master, while the others are slaves. The instrument shows clearly whether a slave engine is running faster or slower than the master. content.question: A jet engine vibration meter is indicating "4". What is the unit of this indication?

key_points: A gas turbine engine is generally providing minimal vibration
Therefore, even a small increase in the level of vibration is a clear indicator of a potential impending failure
An Engine Vibration Monitoring system is fitted to detect mechanical deficiencies in the rotating parts of an engine so that corrective action is taken before greater damage occurs
learning.explanation: A gas turbine engine is generally providing minimal vibration. Therefore, even a small increase in the level of vibration is a clear indicator of a potential impending failure. An Engine Vibration Monitoring system is fitted to detect mechanical deficiencies in the rotating parts of an engine so that corrective action is taken before greater damage occurs. The vibration monitoring unit measures the radial and transverse vibrations using accelerometers operating on the piezo-electric principle. The frequencies of the detected vibrations will be filtered so that only those indicating a potential malfunction are considered, the normal engine frequencies are erased as they’re not relevant to indicate hazardous vibrations. After being filtered, the potentially threatening frequencies are then amplified before being sent to the vibration indicator. The vibration indicator will be either a graduated scale with a pointer or a digital display, showing a value without any unit.

content.question: TAS is obtained from EAS by correcting for…

key_points: Equivalent Airspeed (EAS): In the presence of density error, compressibility error arises
It is possible to rectify CAS solely for compressibility error, resulting in a dynamic pressure termed equivalent airspeed (EAS)
Equivalent airspeed represents CAS corrected exclusively for compressibility error
learning.explanation: Equivalent Airspeed (EAS): In the presence of density error, compressibility error arises. It is possible to rectify CAS solely for compressibility error, resulting in a dynamic pressure termed equivalent airspeed (EAS). Equivalent airspeed represents CAS corrected exclusively for compressibility error. True Airspeed (TAS) and Density Error: Unless the air surrounding the aircraft matches the calibration density of 1225 grams per cubic meter, a condition primarily achievable near sea level, the ASI cannot accurately indicate TAS. Dynamic pressure is directly proportional to density, so at higher altitudes where density decreases, the dynamic pressure for a given TAS is lower compared to the same TAS at sea level. Consequently, the expansion of the ASI capsule is proportionately reduced, leading to an indicated speed lower than the actual speed. In summary, the ASI underestimates true speed at altitude due to density being less than 1225 grams/cubic meter, a discrepancy known as 'density error.' Conversely, if density exceeds the International Standard Atmosphere (ISA) at Mean Sea Level (MSL), the ASI will overstate the true speed. EAS + Density error = TAS

content.question: At flight level and Mach number constant, if OAT decreases, the CAS…

options.C: decreases if OAT is lower than standard temperature, increases in the opposite case.

key_points: M = TAS ÷ LSS If the Mach number is constant, it means that the above equation needs to be balanced
If one of the variables is changing (for example TAS), the other one (LSS) needs to change in the same way to equalize the relationship
If the OAT decreases, the LSS will decrease as well since LSS = 38
learning.explanation: M = TAS ÷ LSS If the Mach number is constant, it means that the above equation needs to be balanced. If one of the variables is changing (for example TAS), the other one (LSS) needs to change in the same way to equalize the relationship. If the OAT decreases, the LSS will decrease as well since LSS = 38.95 x √ (°K). Therefore, to maintain the balance in the above-mentioned equation, the TAS needs to be decreased as well. Think about it in this way. If the temperature decreases, air density is increasing, and you need a lower airspeed relative to the airflow (TAS) to pick up the same dynamic pressure (CAS). Thus, TAS decreases, LSS decreases maintaining a constant Mach number.

A sealed capsule containing international standard atmosphere (ISA) mean sea level (MSL) conditions inside the ambient static pressure feed case, which acts as an altimeter by measuring the static pressure, which it relates to an altitude. learning.explanation: The Mach Number can be defined by the relation between True Airspeed (TAS) and Local Speed of Sound (LSS) as follows: M = TAS ÷ LSS If the Mach number is constant, it means that the above equation needs to be balanced. If one of the variables is changing (for example TAS), the other one (LSS) needs to change in the same way to equalize the relationship. Temperature increases with decreasing altitude. Since the LSS is directly proportional to the temperature, it means the LSS is increasing with decreasing altitude as well. Therefore, the TAS needs to increase as well to balance the above equation and output a constant Mach number. Maximum Operating Speed (VMO/MMO): VMO is a speed that may not be deliberately exceeded in any regime of flight (climb, cruise or descent). options.B: VMO only during all the descent.
options.C: initially MMO, then VMO below a given flight level.
options.D: initially VMO, then MMO below a given flight level.

key_points: In cruise, and generally at higher levels, for the same VMO, the TAS and Mach number increase due to the decrease in density
Therefore, at high levels, it is very unlikely that you reach the VMO
But let’s suppose you’re trying to reach the VMO (just to illustrate this relationship)
learning.explanation: In cruise, and generally at higher levels, for the same VMO, the TAS and Mach number increase due to the decrease in density. Therefore, at high levels, it is very unlikely that you reach the VMO. But let’s suppose you’re trying to reach the VMO (just to illustrate this relationship). By accelerating to reach the VMO, which is an IAS, your TAS and your Mach number will increase, and you will most likely reach your MMO before the VMO. In the same way, at low levels close to the ground, the IAS and the TAS are very close because of the higher density, therefore the VMO becomes the limiting speed. To reach the MMO at a low level, you will need to drastically increase your TAS, which is impossible as you will reach the VMO and damage your structure way before.

content.question: If you are flying through turbulence, you can expect the IVSI to (1) _____. You should (2) _____ gradual changes.

key_points: The Instantaneous VSI or IVSI is an instrument designed to overcome the time lag of the vertical rate display

The sensitivity of an IVSI is very high and this results in the instrument overreacting in turbulent flying conditions
learning.explanation: The Instantaneous VSI or IVSI is an instrument designed to overcome the time lag of the vertical rate display. The design is similar to the traditional barometric VSI but it also features an inertial sensor consisting of a piston suspended by springs that moves in an airtight cylinder connected to the static pressure line, this is called an acceleration pump. The sensitivity of an IVSI is very high and this results in the instrument overreacting in turbulent flying conditions. Small and sudden fluctuations should be ignored, instead pilots should monitor the trend of the vertical speed over time. Gradual changes, which occur in small stages over a long period of time, rather than suddenly, should be responded to slowly. In such conditions, the conventional VSI is superior to the IVSI. content.question:

learning.explanation: 022.02.06.01.09: Define the term ‘unreliable airspeed’ and describe the means by which it can be recognised such as: different airspeed indications between ASIs; unexpected aircraft behaviour; buffeting; aircraft systems warning; aircraft attitude. Unreliable Airspeed describes a situation where the airspeed indicators on an aircraft are providing inaccurate or unreliable readings. Resolution of the discrepancy requires effortful reference to standby airspeed display and/or to pitch/power displays. Pilots may follow incorrect airspeed guidance into an undesired aircraft state or loss of control, because the airspeed display may appear valid and the process of identifying the discrepant display(s) may require substantial time. One of the obvious signs of unreliable airspeed is a difference between airspeed indications of redundant systems, probably accompanied by warnings from other aircraft systems. Boeing would display "IAS disagree" where a discrepancy of > 5 kt exists for > 5 sec. Unexpected aircraft behaviour, such as "Buffeting" or unusual pitch attitude could indicate an unreliable airspeed situation. "Buffeting", for instance, could be an indication of excessive or low speed.

Pilots must bear in mind that altitude changes are not immediately visible on the altimeter. Instead they can rely on an instantaneous vertical speed indicator (IVSI) if installed. The lag error occurs after an aircraft has maintained a constant altitude for an extended period of time and then makes a large, rapid altitude change. For instance, after a rapid descent, altimeter indications are higher than actual.

content.question: The ADC uses, among others, the following parameters as input data…

key_points: Air Data Computers (ADC) converts raw pressure and temperature measurements into electrical signals
Two types of ADC exist – analog and digital

learning.explanation: Air Data Computers (ADC) converts raw pressure and temperature measurements into electrical signals. Two types of ADC exist – analog and digital. Initially, only the temperature and the pitot/static pressures were provided to the ADC. From these inputs it was able to compute and provide airspeed (Pt-Ps = CAS/IAS), Mach number, altitude, TAS and GS indications. However, now the AOA probe also provides inputs to the ADC. All this data is joined together and is transmitted from the ADC to other systems such as the FMS, AFCS, TAWS, TCAS, transponder, EFIS (via the symbol generator) etc. The only temperature MEASURED (not calculated) in an aircraft usually fitted with an ADC (commercial aircraft) is the TAT; there’s no OAT probe. The OAT is internally calculated by the ADC by taking into account the ram rise and the recovery factor.

EASA learning objective 022.02.06.01.10 states: Describe the appropriate procedures available to the pilot in the event of unreliable airspeed indications: combination of a pitch attitude and power setting; ambient wind noise inside the aircraft; use of GPS speed indications and the associated limitations. A persistent discrepancy of more than 5 kts between ASI's will normally trigger a caution message. There will be an 'Unreliable Airspeed' procedure to be actioned. If the pilots are unable to identify the correct ASI reading by comparison with the standby ASI then groundspeed can be used to calculate an approximate airspeed. GNSS and INS/IRS systems have a groundspeed readout, this can be used to calculate TAS by applying the wind values from the computer flight plan. The TAS then has to be converted to IAS to find out which ASI is correct.
