learning.explanation: The airframe may become contaminated by ice, frost or water either whilst it is in flight or when standing on the ground. The formation of ice and frost on the airframe will: - modify the profile of the aerofoil. - increase the roughness of the aircraft surface. - increase the weight of the aircraft. Tests have shown that frost, ice or snow with the thickness and surface roughness of medium or coarse sandpaper reduces lift by as much as 30% and increases drag by 40%. ICING CONDITIONS ‐ Icing conditions exist when the OAT (on ground or after takeoff) or the TAT (in flight) is at or below 10°C and visible moisture in any form is present (such as clouds, fog with visibility of 1 sm (1600 m) or less, rain, snow, sleet or ice crystals). ‐ Icing conditions also exist when the OAT on the ground and for takeoff is at or below 10°C and operating on ramps, taxiways or runways where surface snow, standing water or slush may be ingested by the engines, or freeze on engines, nacelles or engine sensor probes.

learning.explanation: Unreliable airspeed indications can result due to erraneous data from the pitot/static system, AoA vanes, ADIRU, or damage to the radome. Blockages or freezing in the pitot/static system can result in airspeed and altitude indications that are unreliable. This could mean increasing indicated airspeed in a climb, decreasing airspeed in descent, or unpredictable indicated airspeed in cruise. If an unreliable airspeed condition occurs, the flight crew should be familiar with the approximate pitch attitude and thrust setting for each phase of flight. To determine if a reliable source of indicated airspeed is available, the flight crew should assess and compare flight deck indications. To aid the identification of a reliable airspeed indication, ground speed information is available from the FMC (from the INS/GNSS) and on the intrument displays. key_points: The QNH is the calculated pressure at MSL in ISA conditions

learning.explanation: The QNH is the calculated pressure at MSL in ISA conditions. It is calculated using the QFE value measured at the aerodrome and brought to ISA conditions. Therefore, with the QNH set in your altimeter sub-scale, you will be able to read the airfield elevation. The opposite is also true, if you want to know the QNH, you just need to set the airfield elevation in your altimeter and the QNH will be indicated in the sub-scale. The QNH is used at low levels, below the transition level. It is a regional pressure setting, so during your cross-country when passing from one region to another, you will be given a new QNH value. Aerodromes might have different QNH values from the regional ones, so you need to comply with it when approaching an airfield.

content.question: Most modern transport aircraft have three Air Data Inertial Reference Units (ADIRUs). Each ADIRU combines an IRS with _____, which sends barometric altitude and TAS information to the IRS.

key_points: The Air Data and Inertial Reference System (ADIRS) supplies temperature, anemometric, barometric and inertial parameters to the EFIS system (PFD and ND) and to other user systems (FMGC, FADEC, ELAC, SEC, FAC, FWC, SFCC, ATC, GPWS, CFDIU, CPC)
The system includes: ‐ Three identical ADIRUs (Air Data and Inertial Reference Units)

Each ADIRU is divided in two parts, either of which can work separately in case of failure in the other: - The ADR part (Air Data Reference) which supplies barometric altitude, airspeed, Mach, angle of attack, temperature and overspeed warnings
learning.explanation: The Air Data and Inertial Reference System (ADIRS) supplies temperature, anemometric, barometric and inertial parameters to the EFIS system (PFD and ND) and to other user systems (FMGC, FADEC, ELAC, SEC, FAC, FWC, SFCC, ATC, GPWS, CFDIU, CPC). The system includes: ‐ Three identical ADIRUs (Air Data and Inertial Reference Units). Each ADIRU is divided in two parts, either of which can work separately in case of failure in the other: - The ADR part (Air Data Reference) which supplies barometric altitude, airspeed, Mach, angle of attack, temperature and overspeed warnings. - The IR part (Inertial Reference) which supplies attitude, flight path vector, track, heading, accelerations, angular rates, ground speed and aircraft position.

content.question: The advantages of a servo altimeter over a sensitive altimeter include…

options.D: being independent of the aircraft power supply.

key_points: THE SENSITIVE ALTIMETER (figure 1) The sensitive altimeter employs a minimum of two aneroid capsules
This provides for a more accurate measurement of pressure and provides more power to drive the mechanical linkage

The movement of the capsules in response to changes in altitude (pressure) is transmitted via a suitable mechanical linkage to three pointers that display (against a graduated instrument scale) the aeroplane altitude in tens, hundreds, and thousands of feet
learning.explanation: THE SENSITIVE ALTIMETER (figure 1) The sensitive altimeter employs a minimum of two aneroid capsules. This provides for a more accurate measurement of pressure and provides more power to drive the mechanical linkage. The movement of the capsules in response to changes in altitude (pressure) is transmitted via a suitable mechanical linkage to three pointers that display (against a graduated instrument scale) the aeroplane altitude in tens, hundreds, and thousands of feet. The whole assembly is encased in a container, which is fed with static pressure, but is otherwise completely airtight. SERVO ALTIMETERS (figure 2) Servo-assisted altimeters use the same basic principles as sensitive altimeters, whereby pressure changes are measured using the expansion and contraction of evacuated capsules. The instrument uses an electrical servomotor to transmit the movement of conventional aneroid capsules to the instrument display. A digital counter system and a single pointer indicate the altitude. SERVO-ALTIMETER POWER FAILURE In the event of power failure, the servo-altimeter does not function, and warning flags immediately display on the dial, indicating that the AC power supply failed. A standard sensitive altimeter is required as a standby instrument. Servo-altimeters have the following advantages over simple and sensitive altimeters: - At high altitude, very little pressure change takes place for a given change of altitude, with the result that capsule movement is considerably less than for the same change of altitude at lower levels. This factor reduces the efficiency of ordinary altimeters at high levels, whereas the servomechanism picks up a capsule movement as small as 0.0002 in per thousand ft. - Power transmission gives greater accuracy. - There is practically no time lag between the arrival of a new pressure in the instrument, and the positioning of the counters. - Because it is an electrical system, it is possible to correct for pressure error, and incorporate an altitude-alerting device in the system. - Although conventional altimeters now employ digital presentation, it is generally more common with servo-altimeters. The digital presentation reduces the possibility of misreading. - A pointer is still available on the servo-altimeter for use at low level in assessing the rate of change of altitude.

In this case, when the aircraft descends, the pressure inside the case will remain the same as when the static port got blocked, and the differential pressure will increase, showing an increase in airspeed
learning.explanation: If the static ports are blocked by ice, the ASI won’t be fed with static pressure anymore. In this case, when the aircraft descends, the pressure inside the case will remain the same as when the static port got blocked, and the differential pressure will increase, showing an increase in airspeed.

content.question: The pressure capsule of an airspeed indicator is sensitive to the difference.

key_points: The ASI indicates dynamic pressure
Dynamic pressure is the difference between total pressure (static + dynamic) and static pressure
An open-ended tube, called the Pitot tube, facing the relative airflow will transmit the total pressure (Ps + Pd) to a diaphragm (pressure capsule) situated in the instrument case
learning.explanation: The ASI indicates dynamic pressure. Dynamic pressure is the difference between total pressure (static + dynamic) and static pressure. An open-ended tube, called the Pitot tube, facing the relative airflow will transmit the total pressure (Ps + Pd) to a diaphragm (pressure capsule) situated in the instrument case. Another pressure sensor, usually situated on the side of the fuselage and called the static port, measures the static atmospheric pressure. The static pressure is fed to the ASI case and will act on the diaphragm ‘filled’ with total pressure. The static pressure acting on the outside of the diaphragm will cancel the static pressure from inside the diaphragm. The resultant of this differential pressure will be the dynamic pressure (Pt – PS = Pd) which will be mechanically transmitted to a pointer moving over a dial calibrated in knots (kn) or km/h.

content.question: Assuming the flight level and Mach number remain constant, when the OAT decreases…

options.B: CAS remains constant and TAS increases.
options.D: CAS remains constant and TAS decreases.

key_points: M = TAS ÷ LSS If the Mach number is constant, it means that the above equation needs to be balanced
If one of the variables is changing (for example TAS), the other one (LSS) needs to change in the same way to equalize the relationship
If the OAT decreases, the LSS will decrease since LSS = 38
learning.explanation: M = TAS ÷ LSS If the Mach number is constant, it means that the above equation needs to be balanced. If one of the variables is changing (for example TAS), the other one (LSS) needs to change in the same way to equalize the relationship. If the OAT decreases, the LSS will decrease since LSS = 38.95 x √ (°K). Therefore, in order to maintain a constant Mach number (from the above equation), we need to decrease the TAS as well. CAS is the dynamic pressure, which is the number of air molecules that will hit the pitot probe. If the density is increasing, but you maintain a lower airspeed relative to the airflow (TAS), you will pick up the same dynamic pressure (CAS).

ADC’s are used to source and process information from the pitot and static devices
the information received will give information pertaining to temperature, altitude fluctuations, altitude, and airspeed
learning.explanation: The air data computer (ADC) in current aircraft is a device that uses analogue or digital computing techniques to convert pressure and temperature data into electrical signals which are transmitted to the display instruments and to other systems. ADC’s are used to source and process information from the pitot and static devices. the information received will give information pertaining to temperature, altitude fluctuations, altitude, and airspeed. The relationships between TAS, Mach number, temperature, pitot, and static pressures can be expressed as mathematical formulae. The ADC resolves these formulae continuously to produce the required outputs from pressure and temperature inputs in the form of shaft rotations or electrical signals. The digital system uses digital data (binary data) in its assessment and transmission of information.

learning.explanation: If, during flight, the IRS loses its alignment for some reason or the computer fails, a re-initialisation is not possible, because the aircraft cannot be stationary and the IRS cannot verify its position while in motion. The IRS is often paired to an air data computer (ADC), a combination called air data inertial reference unit (ADIRU). The ADC part and IRS part usually feature separate controls. Therefore, it is possible to make a restart attempt on an ADC considered unreliable while at the same time keeping the IRS powered up and running. The ADC will still work after a power interruption/accidental switch off.

content.question: In a barometric type Instantaneous Vertical Speed Indicator (IVSI), what is used to quickly respond to altitude changes and provide instant climb/descent indications?

options.A: An accelerometer mechanically linked to the capsule, to expand it faster.
options.B: An accelerometer to temporarily change the pressure in the capsule.
options.C: A piston to temporarily change the diameter of the metering unit.
options.D: Information from an air data inertial reference system.

key_points: A Vertical Speed Indicator (VSI) is a sensitive differential pressure gauge, which records the rate of change of atmospheric pressure in terms of rate of climb or descent, when an aeroplane departs from level flight

INSTANTANEOUS VERTICAL SPEED INDICATOR (IVSI) The Instantaneous Vertical Speed Indicator (IVSI) consists of the same basic elements as the conventional VSI, but it is additionally fitted with an accelerometer unit that is designed to create a more rapid differential pressure effect, specifically during the initiation of climb or descent
The accelerometer comprises of two small cylinders or dashpots, which contain inertial masses in the form of pistons that are held in balance by springs and their own mass
learning.explanation: A Vertical Speed Indicator (VSI) is a sensitive differential pressure gauge, which records the rate of change of atmospheric pressure in terms of rate of climb or descent, when an aeroplane departs from level flight. INSTANTANEOUS VERTICAL SPEED INDICATOR (IVSI) The Instantaneous Vertical Speed Indicator (IVSI) consists of the same basic elements as the conventional VSI, but it is additionally fitted with an accelerometer unit that is designed to create a more rapid differential pressure effect, specifically during the initiation of climb or descent. The accelerometer comprises of two small cylinders or dashpots, which contain inertial masses in the form of pistons that are held in balance by springs and their own mass. The cylinders are connected in the capillary tube system leading to the capsule and are thus open to the static pressure source. OPERATION OF THE IVSI If a change in vertical motion is initiated, the resultant vertical acceleration (i.e. due to the change in vertical velocity along the aeroplanes vertical axis), produces a force and the pistons are displaced from their neutral position. The pistons are arranged so that one responds to nose up pitch changes (positive G) by reducing the capsule pressure, whilst the other responds to nose down pitch changes (negative G) by increasing the capsule pressure. The piston in the vertical acceleration pump immediately rises in the cylinder and causes a temporary change of pressure in the capsule. The capsule expands/compresses and the pointer will give an instant indication of descent/climb. The accelerometer output will decay after only a few seconds, and the pistons will automatically return to their neutral position, by which time a steady pressure differential is established across the metering unit. The instrument will then continue to behave like a conventional VSI. ERROR The errors are generally the same as those affecting the conventional VSI, although the lag and induced manoeuvre errors are virtually eliminated, with the instrument providing a rapid response to changes in the aeroplanes vertical flight path. The IVSI is affected by the acceleration forces, i.e. g–forces, which act on the pistons during steep turns when the angle of bank is in excess of 40°, and may produce a false reading, known as Turning Error.

content.question: What input does the ADC need to obtain TAS from CAS?

key_points: True Airspeed (TAS) equals CAS corrected for altitude and non-standard temperature
It is the actual speed of an aircraft through the air

Because air density decreases with an increase in altitude, an airplane has to be flown faster at higher altitudes to cause the same pressure difference between pitot impact pressure and static pressure
learning.explanation: True Airspeed (TAS) equals CAS corrected for altitude and non-standard temperature. It is the actual speed of an aircraft through the air. Because air density decreases with an increase in altitude, an airplane has to be flown faster at higher altitudes to cause the same pressure difference between pitot impact pressure and static pressure. Consequently, for a given CAS, the TAS increases as altitude increase. The airspeed indicator displays TAS only at sea level under standard conditions, so you must calculate TAS based on IAS, the current pressure altitude and air temperature. The only temperature MEASURED (not calculated) in an aircraft usually fitted with an ADC (commercial aircraft) is the TAT; there’s no OAT probe. The OAT is internally calculated by the ADC by taking into account the ram rise and the recovery factor. Note: The correct answer here is TAT, but if that is not an option and only SAT is present, then you may have to choose that as the "most correct" answer.

content.question: What happens to TAS and ROC if an aircraft climbs at constant CAS of 300 kt and a vertical speed of 2000 ft/min?

key_points: CAS is IAS corrected for Instrument and Position (Pressure) Error

CLIMB AT CONSTANT CAS IN ISA ATMOSPHERE The rapid rise of Mach number (in this case far exceeding MMO) is the reason why high performance aircraft are flown on CAS (or IAS) for the first part of the climb before transferring to a constant Mach number for the rest of the climb
For a constant CAS as altitude increases, TAS increases, and Mach number increases at a greater rate
learning.explanation: CAS is IAS corrected for Instrument and Position (Pressure) Error. CLIMB AT CONSTANT CAS IN ISA ATMOSPHERE The rapid rise of Mach number (in this case far exceeding MMO) is the reason why high performance aircraft are flown on CAS (or IAS) for the first part of the climb before transferring to a constant Mach number for the rest of the climb. For a constant CAS as altitude increases, TAS increases, and Mach number increases at a greater rate. If TAS increases, the climb gradient and rate of climb decrease because kinetic energy is converted into potential energy. Note: The sum of kinetic energy and potential energy may not exceed the total aircraft energy. The total energy is shared between the need for speed and the need for altitude.

The pressure of the atmosphere is communicated directly to the inner chamber (capsule) and through a calibrated choke or capsule case to the outer chamber

learning.explanation: The principle employed is that of measuring the difference in pressure between two chambers, one of which is enclosed within the other, as shown below. The pressure of the atmosphere is communicated directly to the inner chamber (capsule) and through a calibrated choke or capsule case to the outer chamber. If the pressure changes, as in a climb or descent, the lag between the capsule and outer chamber results in a pressure differential across the metering unit, which is a direct measure of the aeroplane's rate of climb or descent. content.question: If you are flying through turbulence, you can expect the IVSI to (1) _____. You should (2) _____ small fluctuations.

key_points: The Instantaneous VSI or IVSI is an instrument designed to overcome the time lag of the vertical rate display

The design is similar to the traditional barometric VSI but it also features an inertial sensor consisting of a piston suspended by springs that moves in an airtight cylinder connected to the static pressure line, this is called an acceleration pump
The sensitivity of an IVSI is very high and this results in the instrument overreacting in turbulent flying conditions
learning.explanation: The Instantaneous VSI or IVSI is an instrument designed to overcome the time lag of the vertical rate display. The design is similar to the traditional barometric VSI but it also features an inertial sensor consisting of a piston suspended by springs that moves in an airtight cylinder connected to the static pressure line, this is called an acceleration pump. The sensitivity of an IVSI is very high and this results in the instrument overreacting in turbulent flying conditions. Small and sudden fluctuations should be ignored, instead pilots should monitor the trend of the vertical speed over time. Gradual changes, which occur in small stages over a long period of time, rather than suddenly, should be responded to slowly. In such conditions, the conventional VSI is superior to the IVSI. content.question: The vertical speed indicator is fed by…

learning.explanation: The vertical speed indicator senses the rate of change in static air pressure. It consists of a capsule directly fed with static pressure, located in the instrument’s case. The instrument’s case is also fed with static pressure, but through a restricted orifice called the metering unit. When the aircraft changes altitude, the static pressure inside the capsule will immediately vary and alter capsule’s shape. However, the static pressure inside the case won’t change immediately and will lag behind the capsule. The differential pressure will deform the capsule and this movement will be mechanically transmitted to a pointer moving over a vertical speed calibrated dial.

learning.explanation: The simplest form of system, and one which is adopted in several types of small aircraft, consists of a hinged-vane-type sensor mounted in the leading edge of a wing so that the vane protrudes into the airstream. learning.explanation: The pitot and static systems on an aeroplane measure the total pressures created by the forward motion of the aeroplane, and the static pressure surrounding the airframe. In some light aeroplanes the complication and expense of separate pitot head(s) and static sources is often avoided by incorporating both functions into a combined pressure head. The combined head is usually mounted on a pylon below the wing toward the tip, thus reducing the position/pressure error to an acceptable level. Static pressure is admitted to the pressure head through slots or holes cut into the static casing at 90° to the airflow, whilst pitot pressure enters the head via the pitot input port that faces directly into the airflow. The different pressures are fed to the flight instruments via separate, seamless, and corrosion-resistant metal pipelines. This sensor is particularly prone to errors during manoeuvres, when changes in pitch can result in the pitot/static sources being presented to the relative airflow in such a way that the full dynamic pressure is not sensed. More significantly, dynamic pressure effects may also intrude into the static supply.

learning.explanation: There are two main types of AoA sensors in common use. Both detect the angular difference between the relative wind and the fuselage, which is used as a reference plane. One uses a vane (figure 1), known as an alpha-vane, externally mounted to the outside of the fuselage. It is free to rotate in the wind. As the AoA changes, air flowing over the vane changes its angle. The other one (figure 2), known as conical probe, uses two slots in a probe that extends out of the side of the fuselage into the airflow. The slots lead to different sides of movable paddles in a chamber of the unit just inside the fuselage skin. As the AoA varies, the air pressure ported by each of the slots changes and the paddles rotate to neutralize the pressures. Probes and vane detectors are mounted either side of the fuselage. They are usually placed forward of the wing line, to compensate for sideslip or yaw.

learning.explanation: The Mach Number can be defined by the relation between True Airspeed (TAS) and Local Speed of Sound (LSS) as follows: M = TAS ÷ LSS And, LSS = 38.94 x √(Temperature (K)) Meaning that if temperature decreases, LSS decreases. Additionally, it features an inertial sensor consisting of a piston suspended by springs that moves in an airtight cylinder connected to the static pressure line
learning.explanation: Instantaneus VSI (IVSI) An instrument designed to overcome the time lag of the vertical rate display is called an Instantaneous VSI or IVSI. The design is similar to the traditional barometric VSI. Additionally, it features an inertial sensor consisting of a piston suspended by springs that moves in an airtight cylinder connected to the static pressure line. The additional device is called an acceleration pump. The errors are generally the same as those affecting the conventional VSI. However, the lag and induced manoeuvre errors are virtually eliminated, with the instrument providing a rapid response to changes in the aircraft’s vertical flight path. The IVSI is affected by the acceleration forces, i.e. g-forces, which act on the pistons during steep turns when the angle of bank is more than 40° and may produce a false reading, known as Turning Error

content.question: Angle of Attack vane is damaged during the flight. What will happen if you slow down to the stall?

options.A: Everything works as normal using alternate ADC.
options.B: The stall warning system will not be triggered.
options.C: Nothing will happen as the stall warning system receives inputs from the static ports and the pitot tube.
options.D: The stall warning will be immediately triggered.

learning.explanation: 022.02.03.01.04: Give examples of systems that use the AoA as an input, such as: air-data computer; stall warning systems; flight-envelope protection systems. The wing’s angle of attack is the critical factor in determining how close the aircraft is to an aerodynamic stall. Therefore, an angle-of-attack (AoA) sensor is the ultimate stall warning and protection system. Stall warning systems often involve inputs from a broad range of sensors and systems and include a dedicated angle of attack sensor. At a predetermined angle of attack, calculated for each possible configuration, the Angle of Attack sensor triggers the activation of the stick shaker or the audible warning device as appropriate to the aircraft fitment. The stall warning must continue until the angle of attack has been reduced to approximately the initial angle of warning onset. If the angle of attack sensor is damaged, it will not send the required inputs upon reaching a predetermined angle of attack and the stall warning will not be activated. Note: Most modern aircrafts will have redundant instruments, however this is not the case for a small aircraft, for instance.

Dynamic pressure is the difference between the Total pressure (static and dynamic) sensed by the pitot tube and the static pressure sensed by the static port
If there’s a leak in the Total Pressure line, the amount of total pressure will be lower so the resulting dynamic pressure will be lower
learning.explanation: The ASI gives the pilot the airspeed by indicating the dynamic pressure. Dynamic pressure is the difference between the Total pressure (static and dynamic) sensed by the pitot tube and the static pressure sensed by the static port. If there’s a leak in the Total Pressure line, the amount of total pressure will be lower so the resulting dynamic pressure will be lower. Therefore, the instrument will under-read.

learning.explanation: Air Data Computers (ADC) converts raw pressure and temperature measurements into electrical signals. Two types of ADC exist – analog and digital. Initially, only the temperature and the pitot/static pressures were provided to the ADC. From these inputs, it was able to compute and provide airspeed (Pt-Ps = CAS/IAS), Mach number, altitude, TAS, and GS indications. However, now the AOA probe also provides inputs to the ADC. All this data is joined together and is transmitted from the ADC to other systems such as the FMS, AFCS, TAWS, TCAS, transponder, EFIS (via the symbol generator), etc. The only temperature measured in an aircraft usually fitted with an ADC (commercial aircraft) is the TAT; there’s no OAT probe. learning.explanation: An Inertial Reference System (IRS) is not typically utilized as a stand-alone system in contemporary transport aircraft, while being theoretically conceivable. Instead, it frequently works in conjunction with an Air Data Computer (ADC), creating what is known as an Air Data Inertial Reference Unit (ADIRU). Often, there are distinct controls for the IRS portion and the ADC portion. As a result, it is possible to attempt a reset on the ADC that has been identified as unreliable while still maintaining power to the IRS. Because it is impossible to realign the IRS once this aircraft is moving, accidentally shutting down the IRS component would result in the irrevocable loss of IRS navigation functionality for the rest of the flight.

content.question: The response time of a vertical speed detector may be decreased by adding a…

options.C: correction based on an acceleration sensor.

key_points: The Vertical Speed Indicator (VSI) measures the differential pressure between the actual static pressure and the previous static pressure
However, this indication is not immediate and requires several seconds of adjusting - being reliable only when flight is stable

In order to solve this lag error, an instantaneous VSI (IVSI) unit is used which will consist of the same basic elements of a conventional VSI but also employs an accelerometer, designed to create a faster differential pressure effect (especially at the start of a climb or descent)
learning.explanation: The Vertical Speed Indicator (VSI) measures the differential pressure between the actual static pressure and the previous static pressure. However, this indication is not immediate and requires several seconds of adjusting - being reliable only when flight is stable. In order to solve this lag error, an instantaneous VSI (IVSI) unit is used which will consist of the same basic elements of a conventional VSI but also employs an accelerometer, designed to create a faster differential pressure effect (especially at the start of a climb or descent). The IVSI has 2 accelerometers fitted in the static pressure line => as the aircraft manoeuvres, the load factor changes and the accelerometers will move artificially, changing the pressure in the line to overcome lag. The response time of a VSI is, therefore, reduced (making it an IVSI), by fitting of dashpots into the static feed. These dashpots centred with springs sense a pitch change/vertical acceleration and alter the pressure in the static feed line => which reduces the time to react.

The altimeter is working on the same principle – it measures pressure and displays altitude on a calibrated scale with pointers
learning.explanation: The altimeter is a simple barometer, measuring pressure. Atmospheric pressure is inversely proportional to altitude – the higher you climb the lower the atmospheric pressure. The altimeter is working on the same principle – it measures pressure and displays altitude on a calibrated scale with pointers. The main component of the altimeter is an aneroid capsule fitted inside the instrument case. The case has an opening that is linked to the static pressure port located somewhere on the aircraft’s fuselage. When the aircraft climbs, the pressure decreases, and the aneroid capsule expands. This expansion is displayed as an altitude increase through mechanical linkages between the aneroid capsule and the pointers moving over an altitude calibrated dial.

To calculate TAS from CAS, the following variables must be calculated: Density and compressibility. => CAS is calculated from Total Pressure and Static Pressure. => Correction for density comes from static pressure. => Total air temperature (TAT) serves as another input, enabling determination of true airspeed (TAS) by accounting for density changes. content.question:
EAS is obtained from CAS by correcting for:
1 – position error
2 – compressibility
3 – instrument error
4 – density
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: Above a certain speed, the air molecules are hitting the pitot probe too fast to normally flow through the probe
This build-up creates a higher pressure and will result in an erroneous airspeed reading due to a higher dynamic pressure
This is the compressibility error, and it will induce the ASI to over-read
learning.explanation: Above a certain speed, the air molecules are hitting the pitot probe too fast to normally flow through the probe. This build-up creates a higher pressure and will result in an erroneous airspeed reading due to a higher dynamic pressure. This is the compressibility error, and it will induce the ASI to over-read. For instance, the IAS (or CAS) will be too high than it is in reality, and a correction needs to be applied to account for the compressibility error to obtain the Equivalent Air Speed (EAS). The higher the airspeed, the higher the compressibility error. Besides the airspeed, the compressibility error is also influenced by the altitude. In fact, the less dense air at high altitudes is more easily compressed than at lower levels. The ASI’s calibration formulae include a factor addressing the compressibility of the air so that correct dynamic pressure is measured. Compressibility is becoming significant when the TAS exceeds 300 kt or the IAS is greater than 150 kt.

learning.explanation: Static port clogged by ice during the climb: ASI: the reading will gradually decrease, so the instrument will under-read. content.question: Your Mach Number is 0.7, and you are flying at constant CAS. After considerable time passed, all other variables remained the same, but the temperature SAT of -35°C increased to -30°C.

options.A: Mach will increase because it is a function of temperature.
options.B: Mach decreases but, after some time, increases once again because of increasing TAT.
options.C: Mach remains constant because at a constant CAS and pressure altitude, Mach is independent of temperature.
options.D: Mach will decrease because LSS will increase with increases in temperature.

key_points: The speed of sound (LSS) is the speed at which sound or pressure waves move through a gas, liquid, or solid
The speed of sound is proportional to the square root of the temperature; the speed of sound (LSS) will increase as the temperature increases
A higher SAT leads to a higher TAS
learning.explanation: The speed of sound (LSS) is the speed at which sound or pressure waves move through a gas, liquid, or solid. The speed of sound is proportional to the square root of the temperature; the speed of sound (LSS) will increase as the temperature increases. A higher SAT leads to a higher TAS. As the SAT increases, the air molecules become less dense, resulting in a higher TAS for a given CAS. Therefore, in the given scenario, where the temperature SAT increases from -35°C to -30°C, the TAS will also increase. The Mach number (M) is the ratio of the true airspeed (TAS) to the local speed of sound (LSS), and it’s a measure of compressibility. M = TAS / LSS In this scenario, both TAS and LSS increase, therefore Mach number remains constant, given that the CAS remains constant.

learning.explanation: We know the following about pressure and temperature: When an aircraft is in a lower pressure area, the altimeter will overread. The aircrafts true altitude will be lower than indicated. When an aircraft is in a higher-pressure area, the altimeter will under read. The aircrafts true altitude will be higher than indicated. When an aircraft is in a colder airmass than ISA, the altimeter will overread. The aircrafts true altitude will be lower than indicated. When an aircraft is in a warmer airmass than ISA, the altimeter will under read. The aircrafts true altitude will be higher than indicated. Important aspects in this question: It is a very cold winter’s day. The aircraft is flying at an altitude with regional QNH. In the case of this specific question: Because it is a very cold winter’s day the density is increased. The altimeter will overread and the true altitude will be lower than indicated. If you would go up 27 feet the amount of pressure would decrease faster than in ISA conditions, it would be more than 1 hPa (millibar). So that is why at the altitude of the summit the pressure would be lower than in normal standard atmosphere conditions (ISA). Compared to the elevation of the summit the aneroid altimeter will give a higher indication. And this would be a dangerous condition when you fly in IMC conditions because you have less clearance with the mountain. Remember the mnemonic: Flying from high to low, look out below! content.question: What is the working principle of a barometric type of VSI?

options.B: It is to compare a dynamic and a static pressure.

key_points: A barometric type Vertical Speed Indicator (VSI) uses the rate of pressure change to give the rate of climb or descent indications
Vertical speed indicators are supplied with static pressure from the static ports
It consists of a capsule directly fed with static pressure, located in the instrument’s case
learning.explanation: A barometric type Vertical Speed Indicator (VSI) uses the rate of pressure change to give the rate of climb or descent indications. Vertical speed indicators are supplied with static pressure from the static ports. It consists of a capsule directly fed with static pressure, located in the instrument’s case. The instrument’s case is also fed with static pressure, but through a restricted orifice called the metering unit. When the aircraft changes altitude, the static pressure inside the capsule will immediately vary and alter capsule’s shape. However, the static pressure inside the case won’t change immediately and will lag behind the capsule. The differential pressure will deform the capsule and this movement will be mechanically transmitted to a pointer moving over a vertical speed calibrated dial. The VSI is supplied with static pressure only, and thus is only affected by blockage of the static port of leakage of the static pressure line.

content.question: During a descent at a constant Mach number below the tropopause in standard atmosphere:

key_points: M = TAS ÷ LSS If the Mach number is constant, it means that the above equation needs to be balanced
If one of the variables is changing (for example TAS), the other one (LSS) needs to change in the same way to equalize the relationship
If the OAT increases (the aircraft is descending), the LSS will increase since LSS = 38
learning.explanation: M = TAS ÷ LSS If the Mach number is constant, it means that the above equation needs to be balanced. If one of the variables is changing (for example TAS), the other one (LSS) needs to change in the same way to equalize the relationship. If the OAT increases (the aircraft is descending), the LSS will increase since LSS = 38.95 x √ (°K). Therefore, in order to maintain a constant Mach number (from the above equation), we need to increase the TAS as well. If the TAS is increased, it means that the aircraft will have a bigger forward speed relative to the airflow, and higher dynamic pressure will build up on the leading surfaces of the aircraft. Since the dynamic pressure (Pd) is equivalent to the IAS/CAS, it means that the IAS will also increase under these conditions.

content.question: The parameter that determines the relationship between EAS and TAS is…

key_points: Dynamic pressure varies with the airspeed and the density of the air
Since the ASI is calibrated with the ISA air density, it will give erroneous indications anytime the air density is different from the standard ISA density
This is called the density error
learning.explanation: Dynamic pressure varies with the airspeed and the density of the air. Since the ASI is calibrated with the ISA air density, it will give erroneous indications anytime the air density is different from the standard ISA density. This is called the density error. Density decreases with altitude and the IAS, and thus the EAS will become gradually lower than the TAS. To calculate the appropriate correction, you can use the following formula: EAS = TAS x √ (ρ ÷ ρO) Where: ρ: density of the air at the aircraft’s altitude. ρO: density of the air at MSL.

content.question:
TAS is obtained from the IAS by correcting for the:
1 – instrument error
2 – position error
3 – compressibility
4 – density
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: To obtain the TAS from the IAS, you need to go through all the corrections of each intermediate until reaching the TAS
This means you need to correct for position and instrument error to get the CAS
Then, you need to apply a compressibility correction to obtain the EAS
learning.explanation: To obtain the TAS from the IAS, you need to go through all the corrections of each intermediate until reaching the TAS. This means you need to correct for position and instrument error to get the CAS. Then, you need to apply a compressibility correction to obtain the EAS. And finally, you will apply a density correction to the EAS to obtain the TAS. The dynamic pressure is a function of airspeed and density of the air. The ASI being calibrated for ISA conditions, any other air density will indicate an erroneous airspeed on the ASI. For instance, density reduces with increasing altitude and the IAS, and thus EAS will become progressively lower than the TAS.

key_points: AIR DATA SYSTEM In many large aircraft currently in service, the conventional pressure instruments which show altitude, airspeed and Mach Number are replaced by indicators displaying information generated by a central computer, the Air Data Computer (ADC)
The computer unit and displays, together with the sensors of the basic data of pitot pressure, static pressure and air temperature, and a power-pack, form the aircraft’s Air Data System (ADS)
PITOT - STATIC SYSTEM In a typical aircraft, identical sets of air data instruments are provided on the Captain’s and First Officer’s instrument panels
learning.explanation: AIR DATA SYSTEM In many large aircraft currently in service, the conventional pressure instruments which show altitude, airspeed and Mach Number are replaced by indicators displaying information generated by a central computer, the Air Data Computer (ADC). The computer unit and displays, together with the sensors of the basic data of pitot pressure, static pressure and air temperature, and a power-pack, form the aircraft’s Air Data System (ADS). PITOT - STATIC SYSTEM In a typical aircraft, identical sets of air data instruments are provided on the Captain’s and First Officer’s instrument panels. Each set of instruments is connected to one of two (allowing redundancy) ADCs fed from independent pitot and static sources, which can be cross- connected. In addition to the indicators powered by the two ADCs there is a standby barometric altimeter and a standby airspeed indicator, fed direct from pitot and static sources separate from those used for the ADCs. Each of the three independent pitot-static systems makes use of cross-coupled static vents located on each side of the fuselage. This arrangement is designed to reduce error due to side-slip or yaw. SYSTEM REDUNDANCY Provision for blockages and/or failure of an ADC is made through change-over cocks that permit an alternative static source to be connected to the computer or by the use of electrical switching that enables the Captain’s instrument to be fed from the First Officer’s ADC and vice versa. The Manoeuvre Induced Error is caused by changes in the aeroplanes attitude and/or configuration and is normally only short term. The main sources of error are normally in the static supply. The pressure error changes if any of the following vary: - Airspeed - Angle of attack - Configuration (flap setting, undercarriage etc) - Position of the pitot/static sources and sideslip.

content.question: What inputs does the Air Data Computer need to convert CAS into TAS?

key_points: AIR DATA COMPUTER (ADC) The input data for the ADC are Total Pressure (from the pitot tube), Static Pressure (from the Static Port) and Total Air Temperature (derived from resistance sensors)
Once all signals are in an electronic or digital format the computer can calculate output parameters such as barometric altitude, flight level, CAS, TAS, SAT
To calculate TAS from CAS, the following variables must be calculated: Density and compressibility
learning.explanation: AIR DATA COMPUTER (ADC) The input data for the ADC are Total Pressure (from the pitot tube), Static Pressure (from the Static Port) and Total Air Temperature (derived from resistance sensors). Once all signals are in an electronic or digital format the computer can calculate output parameters such as barometric altitude, flight level, CAS, TAS, SAT. To calculate TAS from CAS, the following variables must be calculated: Density and compressibility. => CAS is calculated from Total Pressure and Static Pressure. => Correction for density and compressibility comes from SAT and static pressure. SAT is calculated from Mach number and TAT. As the ADC already has static and dynamic pressure inputs, the answer is TAT. Note: The only possible correct option for this question was SAT for a long time, but we received some recent feedback indicating that TAT was an available option instead of SAT, and after checking it wasn't referring to a different question, we have changed this over in our database. This is much more correct now, and we hope that all EASA authorities have made this change, but please keep us informed about what you see in the real exam, thank you! In summary, the correct answer here is TAT, but if that is not an option and only SAT is present, then you may have to choose that as the "most correct" answer.

content.question:
Given:
Pt: total pressure
Ps: static pressure
Pd: dynamic pressure
The altitude indicator measures.

key_points: PRINCIPLE OF THE AIRSPEED INDICATOR (ASI) When an aeroplane is stationary on the ground it is subject to normal atmospheric or static pressure, which acts equally on all parts of the aeroplane structure

In flight, the aeroplane experiences an additional pressure due to the aeroplane's motion through the air, which is known as dynamic pressure, and is dependent upon the forward motion of the aeroplane and the density of the air, according to the following formula: Pt = 1/2 ρ V2 + PS Pt = total or pitot pressure (also known as total head pressure or stagnation pressure) PS = static pressure ρ = air density V = velocity of the aeroplane (TAS) Re-arranging the formula, the difference between the pitot and static pressures is equal to 1⁄2 ρ V2 (dynamic pressure)
The airspeed indicator thus measures the pressure differential between the two sources, and provides a display indication graduated in units of speed
learning.explanation: PRINCIPLE OF THE AIRSPEED INDICATOR (ASI) When an aeroplane is stationary on the ground it is subject to normal atmospheric or static pressure, which acts equally on all parts of the aeroplane structure. In flight, the aeroplane experiences an additional pressure due to the aeroplane's motion through the air, which is known as dynamic pressure, and is dependent upon the forward motion of the aeroplane and the density of the air, according to the following formula: Pt = 1/2 ρ V2 + PS Pt = total or pitot pressure (also known as total head pressure or stagnation pressure) PS = static pressure ρ = air density V = velocity of the aeroplane (TAS) Re-arranging the formula, the difference between the pitot and static pressures is equal to 1⁄2 ρ V2 (dynamic pressure). The airspeed indicator thus measures the pressure differential between the two sources, and provides a display indication graduated in units of speed. THE ALTIMETER The altimeter is an instrument that is designed to measure static pressure and, using the conditions of the standard atmosphere, convert that pressure into a value of altitude. Re-arranging the above formula, the difference between total pressure and dynamic pressure (1⁄2 ρ V2) is equal to Static pressure. Pt - (1/2 ρ V2) = PS

content.question: In-flight, the Total Air Temperature (TAT) is the sum of the Static Air Temperature (SAT) and the...

options.A: kinetic heating; TAT is equal to or higher than OAT.
options.B: combination of kinetic and adiabatic heating; TAT is lower than OAT.
options.C: combination of kinetic and adiabatic heating; TAT is higher than OAT.
options.D: adiabatic heating; TAT is equal to or lower than OAT.

key_points: As aircraft speed increases, the measured temperature exceeds that of the still air
This is caused by a combination of kinetic (friction) and adiabatic (compression) heating
KINETIC HEATING As the speed increases, more and more molecules of air per second impact against the flat plate at the surfaces of the probe
learning.explanation: As aircraft speed increases, the measured temperature exceeds that of the still air. This is caused by a combination of kinetic (friction) and adiabatic (compression) heating. KINETIC HEATING As the speed increases, more and more molecules of air per second impact against the flat plate at the surfaces of the probe. This causes a temperature rise due to friction. ADIABATIC HEATING It is caused by a conversion of energy, not a direct application of heat. In the Remote Reading temperature probe, the outside airflow which may be several hundred knots is brought virtually to rest in the platinum measurement chamber very rapidly. The energy of the moving air is released in the form of a temperature rise. The laws of thermodynamics are such that the combination of kinetic and adiabatic heating will always add up to a figure known as the Total Ram Rise. Static Air Temperature (SAT): SAT is the temperature of the undisturbed air through which the aircraft is about to fly. OAT on its own is usually taken to mean SAT. Total Air Temperature (TAT): TAT is the maximum temperature attainable by the air when brought to rest adiabatically. Ram Rise: Ram rise is the difference between the SAT and the TAT (Total Ram Rise) or the difference between the SAT and the RAT (Measured Ram Rise). TAT = SAT + Ram Rise

content.question:
Refer to figure.
The null-seeking (slotted) probe AoA sensor of (1) _____ will automatically rotate (2) _____ to automatically seek a balance point.

key_points: Conical slotted probe – consists of a cylindrical case extending from the aircraft’s skin with a central shaft perpendicular to the relative airflow, which is free to rotate through a limited range of angles
The central extending shaft is fitted with two rows of front-facing slots cut near the outer end of the shaft
The airflow entering the slots is directed through internal ducts to two paddle compartments found inside the cylindrical case
learning.explanation: Conical slotted probe – consists of a cylindrical case extending from the aircraft’s skin with a central shaft perpendicular to the relative airflow, which is free to rotate through a limited range of angles. The central extending shaft is fitted with two rows of front-facing slots cut near the outer end of the shaft. The airflow entering the slots is directed through internal ducts to two paddle compartments found inside the cylindrical case. The working principle is based on the pressure sensing of the relative airflow flowing through the slots. The pressure from one slot will affect the position of both paddles – one duct will make the paddles rotate in a clockwise direction, and the other duct will induce an anti-clockwise rotation of the shaft. As long as the pressure sensed through the slots (and transmitted through the ducts) is equal, the paddles are not moving. However, if the shaft is displaced in regard to the relative airflow (with aircraft’s pitch changes), a higher pressure will be transmitted to the paddles through one of the ducts, and the shaft will rotate. This rotation is transmitted to a potentiometer and the output voltage, proportional to the angle of attack (AoA), is further sent to the different warning devices and systems requiring the AoA. ---------------------------------- As you can see, the probe A has the lower slot that is more exposed into the relative airflow than the upper slot. Therefore, more pressure is going to flow through that lower slot. This will cause a higher pressure over the associated paddle which will push over it and induce an anti-clockwise rotation of the probe. Following the same reasoning, you can easily understand the motion of the probes illustrated in the other figures: Probe B will induce a clockwise rotation of the probe. Probe C is almost totally aligned with the relative airflow, therefore, considering the simplicity of the diagram, the probe will not have any movement. Probe D doesn’t seem to have the relative airflow directly facing it (= no air flowing through the slots).

content.question: Below the tropopause in standard atmosphere, when climbing at a constant Mach number…

key_points: M = TAS ÷ LSS If the Mach number is constant, it means that the above equation needs to be balanced

Temperature decreases with increasing altitude
learning.explanation: M = TAS ÷ LSS If the Mach number is constant, it means that the above equation needs to be balanced. If one of the variables is changing (for example TAS), the other one (LSS) needs to change in the same way to equalize the relationship. Temperature decreases with increasing altitude. Since the LSS is directly proportional to the temperature, it means the LSS is decreasing with increasing altitude as well. Therefore, the TAS needs to decrease as well to balance the above equation and output a constant Mach number. If you struggle to understand the equation as it is, try to replace the TAS and LSS with actual numbers and verify the resultant Mach number variation.

key_points: In high speed aircraft the Machmeter is an essential instrument
As an aircraft approaches the local speed of sound the airflow over some parts of the fuselage or wings may be accelerated up to the speed of sound and a shock wave will form
These shock waves cause more drag, less lift, Mach tuck, buffeting, and reduction in control effectiveness or loss of control
learning.explanation: In high speed aircraft the Machmeter is an essential instrument. As an aircraft approaches the local speed of sound the airflow over some parts of the fuselage or wings may be accelerated up to the speed of sound and a shock wave will form. These shock waves cause more drag, less lift, Mach tuck, buffeting, and reduction in control effectiveness or loss of control. (Mach tuck is a downward-pitching sudden change of trim which can be severe). In order to avoid danger associated with flight at high Mach numbers, a limiting Mach Number will be specified for each aircraft, based on flight trials. This must not be exceeded. It is known as MMO. The Machmeter therefore displays the present Mach number so that the pilot can keep his speed below the particular MMO for his aircraft and avoid the problems associated with high speed flight.

key_points: Air Data Computers (ADC) converts raw pressure and temperature measurements into electrical signals
Two types of ADC exist – analog and digital

learning.explanation: Air Data Computers (ADC) converts raw pressure and temperature measurements into electrical signals. Two types of ADC exist – analog and digital. Initially, only the temperature and the pitot/static pressures were provided to the ADC. From these inputs, it was able to compute and provide airspeed (Pt-Ps = CAS/IAS), Mach number, altitude, TAS, and GS indications. However, now the AOA probe also provides inputs to the ADC. All this data is joined together and is transmitted from the ADC to other systems such as the FMS, AFCS, TAWS, TCAS, transponder, EFIS (via the symbol generator) etc. The only temperature measured in an aircraft usually fitted with an ADC (commercial aircraft) is the TAT; there’s no OAT probe. The OAT is internally calculated by the ADC by taking into account the ram rise and the recovery factor.

learning.explanation: Due to the motion of the aircraft in flight, the relative airflow will be accelerated over the fuselage, creating a lower static pressure. This means that the air pressure all around the aircraft is slightly lower than inside. In case of venting of the back-up static source located in the cockpit, air from the cockpit (from high pressure) will flow outside (to lower pressure) => aerodynamic suction. This will cause the pressure in the cockpit to decrease and become lower than the static pressure around the aircraft and will cause the following: Altimeter over reads. Airspeed over reads. learning.explanation: TRUE AIRSPEED (TAS) The actual speed of the aeroplane relative to the undisturbed air surrounding the aeroplane is referred to as the true airspeed. True airspeed is equal to the EAS divided by the square root of the relative density. It therefore takes account of the density of the atmosphere. The Airspeed Indicator is calibrated for ‘standard’ sea level density, so it will only read TAS if the density of the air through which the aircraft is flying is 1.225 kg/m3. The ICAO standard atmosphere assumes the following mean sea level values: Temperature: 15°C Pressure: 1013.25 hPa Density: 1.225 kg/m3.

learning.explanation: A mechanical machmeter looks more like a complex airspeed indicator. In fact, the instrument consists of 2 capsules and several mechanical connections to provide the Mach number. The altitude capsule (aneroid) and the pitot capsule are connected through a ratio arm (the main mechanical connection) and convert the pitot-static pressure into Mach number. Therefore, you would be tempted to answer with both ‘aneroid capsule’ and ‘differential pressure capsule’. However, the question is asking specifically about the VMO/MMO pointer connection. In fact, the barber pole is connected only to the aneroid capsule as it is calibrated to indicate the MMO according to the variation of the Local Speed of Sound (LSS). LSS is inversely proportional to altitude and reaching a certain altitude the MMO will start decreasing and become the limiting speed (instead of VMO). Therefore, altitude is the most important variable and it’s measured by the aneroid capsule inside the machmeter.

learning.explanation: Maintaining a constant CAS at a constant flight level means that a given amount of molecules equivalent to the CAS, enter the pitot probe. If the OAT increases, the air will expand, and the molecules will be spread further apart. Therefore, in order to maintain a constant CAS, the TAS needs to be increased. Now look at the following formula: M = TAS ÷ LSS The LSS varies with temperature, so if OAT increases => LSS increases. Therefore, by referring again to the Mach number formula you can see that both TAS and LSS increase when OAT increases. Therefore, the Mach number will remain constant.

content.question: The principle of the Mach indicator is based on the computation of the ratio.

key_points: A mechanical machmeter looks like a complex airspeed indicator
The instrument consists of 2 capsules and several mechanical connections to display the Mach number
The altitude capsule (aneroid) and the pitot capsule are connected through a ratio arm (the main mechanical connection) and convert the pitot-static pressure into a Mach number
learning.explanation: A mechanical machmeter looks like a complex airspeed indicator. The instrument consists of 2 capsules and several mechanical connections to display the Mach number. The altitude capsule (aneroid) and the pitot capsule are connected through a ratio arm (the main mechanical connection) and convert the pitot-static pressure into a Mach number. In simple words, the machmeter is a simple airspeed indicator containing an altitude capsule, giving as output the ratio between dynamic and static pressure. M = (Pt – Ps) ÷ Ps Pt: Pitot pressure (total). Ps: Static pressure. There’s no temperature measuring element in the machmeter, so the variations in temperature and density from the standard atmosphere have no effect on the indicated Mach number. It is true that the Mach number is the ratio between the TAS and the LSS. But, as both the TAS and the LSS are dependent on temperature, it can be proven through derivation and other formulas that are not part of EASA’s learning objectives.

key_points: AIR DATA COMPUTER (ADC) An Air Data Computer (ADC) is used by aircrafts to acquire data from pitot and static pressure sensors, data buses and analog inputs and convert those raw inputs into electrical signals, obtaining key air data parameters such as altitude, airspeed, height deviation and temperature to ensure safe and accurate flight detail, on both rotary and fixed wing aircraft
Two types of ADC exist – analog and digital
Initially, only the temperature and the pitot/static pressures were provided to the ADC
learning.explanation: AIR DATA COMPUTER (ADC) An Air Data Computer (ADC) is used by aircrafts to acquire data from pitot and static pressure sensors, data buses and analog inputs and convert those raw inputs into electrical signals, obtaining key air data parameters such as altitude, airspeed, height deviation and temperature to ensure safe and accurate flight detail, on both rotary and fixed wing aircraft. Two types of ADC exist – analog and digital. Initially, only the temperature and the pitot/static pressures were provided to the ADC. From these inputs it was able to compute and provide airspeed (Pt - Ps = CAS/IAS), Mach number, altitude, TAS and GS indications. However, now, the AOA probe also provides inputs to the ADC. All this data is joined together and is transmitted from the ADC to other systems such as the FMS, AFCS, TAWS, TCAS, transponder, EFIS (via the symbol generator) etc. The only temperature measured in an aircraft usually fitted with an ADC (commercial aircraft) is the TAT; there’s no OAT probe. The OAT is internally calculated by the ADC by taking into account the ram rise and the recovery factor.

content.question: The maximum TAS is obtained at…

options.B: all the Flight Level(s) where M = MMO.
options.C: the Flight Level at which simultaneously CAS = VMO and M = MMO.
options.D: all the Flight Level(s) where CAS = VMO.

key_points: During a climb, the airplane will initially climb at a constant CAS, resulting in an increase in TAS due to the decreasing air density with altitude
This means that the TAS will continuously increase during a climb
But, at higher altitudes, the LSS is much lower than at the ground level, so the aircraft will be limited by the Mach number
learning.explanation: During a climb, the airplane will initially climb at a constant CAS, resulting in an increase in TAS due to the decreasing air density with altitude. This means that the TAS will continuously increase during a climb. But, at higher altitudes, the LSS is much lower than at the ground level, so the aircraft will be limited by the Mach number. The aircraft will eventually reach an altitude where if it continues to maintain a constant CAS, the TAS will continue to increase and shockwaves will form over the wing as the aircraft will reach the critical Mach number. Therefore, there needs to be a certain altitude from which the aircraft is switching from maintaining a constant CAS, to maintaining a constant Mach number. This altitude is called the changeover altitude and from this point, the aircraft will maintain a constant Mach number. M = TAS ÷ LSS If the Mach number is constant, it means that the above equation needs to be balanced. At the changeover altitude, LSS continues to decrease (because of the decreasing temperature with height), so the TAS (and the CAS) needs to be decreased to maintain a constant Mach number. To summarize: CAS is constant and TAS is continuously increasing until the changeover altitude where VMO = MMO. At the changeover altitude, the Mach number is constant and the TAS and CAS decrease.

learning.explanation: A pitot tube measures Pitot (Total) Pressure, it's positioned parallel to the airflow with its open end facing forwards. A static port senses Static Pressure, there's normally more than one and they're positioned at right angles to the airflow on the fuselage. A combined pressure head has a pitot tube and static port on the same probe. Although not as accurate as separate ports they are a cheap practical solution for light aircraft. A moving mass of air entering the pitot tube has a Total Pressure made up of Dynamic Pressure and Static Pressure. Dynamic pressure cannot be measured directly, it's derived by subtracting Static from Total Pressure The wording of the question and answers are rather ambiguous as a combined pressure head actually senses total and static pressure, dynamic pressure is derived from total pressure in a mechanical airspeed indicator or air data computer. In the abscence of an answer that includes total pressure the 'most correct' of the available options is Dynamic pressure and static pressure

key_points: In many large aircraft currently in service, the conventional pressure instruments which show altitude, airspeed and Mach Number are replaced by indicators displaying information generated by a central computer, the Air Data Computer (ADC)

learning.explanation: In many large aircraft currently in service, the conventional pressure instruments which show altitude, airspeed and Mach Number are replaced by indicators displaying information generated by a central computer, the Air Data Computer (ADC). The computer unit and displays, together with the sensors of the basic data of pitot pressure, static pressure and air temperature, and a power-pack, form the aircraft’s Air Data System (ADS). In a typical aircraft, identical sets of air data instruments are provided on the Captain’s and First Officer’s instrument panels. Each set of instruments is connected to one of two (allowing redundancy) ADCs fed from independent pitot and static sources, which can be cross-connected. In its basic format, an ADC is an analogue device that produces electrical signals equivalent to pitot and static pressures, and Total Air Temperature (TAT). These signals are computed within the ADC to produce electrical output signals, which are equivalent to: - Altitude - CAS - Vertical speed - Mach number - TAS

content.question: Which option correctly completes the statement on Angle of Attack sensors? Null-seeking (slotted) probe and vane-detector Angle of Attack sensors are connected to a (1) _____ contact and both types are subject to (2) _____ error, which can be corrected in the ADC.

Both detect the angular difference between the relative wind and the fuselage, which is used as a reference plane
One uses a vane (figure 1), known as an alpha vane, externally mounted to the outside of the fuselage
learning.explanation: There are two main types of AoA sensors in common use. Both detect the angular difference between the relative wind and the fuselage, which is used as a reference plane. One uses a vane (figure 1), known as an alpha vane, externally mounted to the outside of the fuselage. It is free to rotate in the wind. As the AoA changes, air flowing over the vane changes its angle. The other (figure 2) uses two slots in a probe that extends out of the side of the fuselage into the airflow. The slots lead to different sides of movable paddles in a chamber of the unit just inside the fuselage skin. As the AoA varies, the air pressure ported by each of the slots changes and the paddles rotate to neutralize the pressures. The shaft upon which the paddles rotate connects to a potentiometer wiper contact that is part of the unit. The same is true of the shaft of the alpha vane. The changing resistance of the potentiometer is used in a balanced bridge circuit to signal a motor in the indicator to move the pointer proportional to the AoA. AoA sensors of the type described are subject to position error since airflow around the alpha vane and slotted probe changes somewhat with airspeed and aircraft attitude. The errors are small, but can be corrected in the ADC.

content.question:
Given:
Ts = static air temperature (SAT)
Tt = total air temperature (TAT)
Kr = recovery coefficient
M = Mach number
The approximate total temperature can be expressed by the formula.

key_points: The temperature is an important parameter to be measured in an aircraft as it influences the altitude, speed, performance, etc
The Outside Air Temperature (OAT), also called Static Air Temperature (SAT), is simply the temperature you will find at a given altitude without any motion or other factors impacting the temperature
The Total Air Temperature (TAT) is the OAT plus the kinetic heating (ram rise) due to compressibility resulting from the aircraft’s motion through the air
learning.explanation: The temperature is an important parameter to be measured in an aircraft as it influences the altitude, speed, performance, etc. The Outside Air Temperature (OAT), also called Static Air Temperature (SAT), is simply the temperature you will find at a given altitude without any motion or other factors impacting the temperature. The Total Air Temperature (TAT) is the OAT plus the kinetic heating (ram rise) due to compressibility resulting from the aircraft’s motion through the air. Therefore, the TAT can only be higher or equal to the SAT. Relationship between the TAT and SAT using the Mach number: TAT = SAT (1 + 0.2M2) SAT = TAT ÷ (1 + K x 0.2 x M2) Relationship between the TAT and SAT using the TAS: TAT = SAT + (TAS ÷ 100)2 SAT = TAT – K (TAS ÷ 100)2 Where K is the recovery factor (the percentage of the measured ram rise). The recovery factor (K) represents the percentage of the kinetic energy of the relative airflow that the temperature probe recovers in reducing the velocity of the airstream. Therefore, for a recovery factor of 0.85, the sensing element will measure the ambient air temperature (SAT) plus 85% of the ram rise.

content.question:
The angle of attack transmitter placed laterally on the forward part of the fuselage supplies an electrical signal which can indicate the angular position of:
1 – a specific slaved pitot probe
2 – a vane detector
3 – a conical slotted probe
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is…

key_points: The most common angle of attack sensors are the conical slotted probes and the vane-type angle of attack probes

Conical slotted probe – consists of a cylindrical case extending from the aircraft’s skin with a central shaft perpendicular to the relative airflow, which is free to rotate through a limited range of angles
The central extending shaft is fitted with two rows of front-facing slots cut near the outer end of the shaft
learning.explanation: The most common angle of attack sensors are the conical slotted probes and the vane-type angle of attack probes. Conical slotted probe – consists of a cylindrical case extending from the aircraft’s skin with a central shaft perpendicular to the relative airflow, which is free to rotate through a limited range of angles. The central extending shaft is fitted with two rows of front-facing slots cut near the outer end of the shaft. The airflow entering the slots is directed through internal ducts to two paddle compartments found inside the cylindrical case. The working principle is based on the pressure sensing of the relative airflow flowing through the slots. The pressure from one slot will affect the position of both paddles – one duct will make the paddles rotate in a clockwise direction, and the other duct will induce an anti-clockwise rotation of the shaft. As long as the pressure sensed through the slots (and transmitted through the ducts) is equal, the paddles are not moving. However, if the shaft is displaced in regard to the relative airflow (with aircraft’s pitch changes), a higher pressure will be transmitted to the paddles through one of the ducts, and the shaft will rotate. This rotation is transmitted to a potentiometer and the output voltage, proportional to the angle of attack (AoA), is further sent to the different warning devices and systems requiring the AoA. Vane-type AoA probe – consists of the same cylindrical case fitted inside the aircraft with a small airfoil-shaped vane extending out of the aircraft skin. The vane is facing the relative airflow and is usually situated in a place where position error is not significant as it can affect the AoA probe’s indication. The changes in the AoA are picked-up by a synchro and are transmitted to other systems or warning devices.

learning.explanation: What the examiner calls a peripheral device is simply a probe or any sensor. Initially, only the temperature and the pitot/static pressures were provided to the ADC. From these inputs, it was able to compute and provide airspeed (Pt-Ps = CAS/IAS), Mach number, altitude, TAS, and GS indications. However, now the AOA probe also provides inputs to the ADC. All this data is joined together and is transmitted from the ADC to other systems such as the FMS, AFCS, TAWS, TCAS, transponder, EFIS (via the symbol generator), etc. The radio altitude is not measured by or transmitted to the ADC. The same stands for the vertical accelerometers that are part of the IRS. The standby altitude and airspeed measurements are totally part of the ADC, however, this data is the primary input to the ADC. As mentioned above, the AOA probe came at a later stage and has only been integrated into the ADC circuit to provide the angle of attack, hence being called a peripheral “device”.

content.question: Give the meaning of the acronym PUDSOD.

options.C: Previously used DME source of distance measurement
options.D: Performance unit drive system on drive

key_points: PRINCIPLE OF THE AIRSPEED INDICATOR (ASI) When an aeroplane is stationary on the ground it is subject to normal atmospheric or static pressure, which acts equally on all parts of the aeroplane structure

In flight, the aeroplane experiences an additional pressure due to the aeroplane's motion through the air, which is known as dynamic pressure, and is dependent upon the forward motion of the aeroplane and the density of the air
The airspeed indicator thus measures the pressure differential between the two sources, and provides a display indication graduated in units of speed
learning.explanation: PRINCIPLE OF THE AIRSPEED INDICATOR (ASI) When an aeroplane is stationary on the ground it is subject to normal atmospheric or static pressure, which acts equally on all parts of the aeroplane structure. In flight, the aeroplane experiences an additional pressure due to the aeroplane's motion through the air, which is known as dynamic pressure, and is dependent upon the forward motion of the aeroplane and the density of the air. The airspeed indicator thus measures the pressure differential between the two sources, and provides a display indication graduated in units of speed. BLOCKAGES - PITOT TUBE (figure 1) A blockage of the pitot tube, possibly due to ice, causes the ASI to not respond to changes of speed in level flight. The capsule behaves as a barometer or altimeter capsule, and reacts to changes in the static pressure. If the aeroplane climbs, the ASI indicates an increase in airspeed (over-read) and if it descends, it indicates a decrease in airspeed (under-read). BLOCKAGES - PITOT TUBE (figure 2) A blocked static source during descent will mean that the ‘old’ (higher altitude) static pressure surrounding the capsule will be lower than it should be, so that if the pitot supply is normal the ASI will over-read. A climb with blocked static source and normal pitot air will result in the ASI under-reading. With a blocked static source, the ASI over-reads in a descent. A useful mnemonic for examinations is PUDSOD, which stands for: ‘Pitot Blocked: – Under-reads in Descent Static Blocked: – Over-reads in Descent’ The opposite of this can also be concluded: ‘Pitot Blocked: – Over-reads in Climb Static Blocked: – Under-reads in Climb’

The design is similar to the traditional barometric VSI but it also features an inertial sensor consisting of a piston suspended by springs that moves in an airtight cylinder connected to the static pressure line, this is called an acceleration pump

learning.explanation: The Instantaneous VSI or IVSI is an instrument designed to overcome the time lag of the vertical rate display. The design is similar to the traditional barometric VSI but it also features an inertial sensor consisting of a piston suspended by springs that moves in an airtight cylinder connected to the static pressure line, this is called an acceleration pump. The sensitivity of an IVSI is very high and this results in the instrument over reacting in turbulent flying conditions. Therefore, small fluctuations should be ignored, pilots should monitor the trend of the vertical speed over time. In such conditions, the conventional VSI is superior to the IVSI.

content.question: EAS is obtained from CAS by correcting for…

key_points: Above a certain speed, the air molecules are hitting the pitot probe too fast to normally flow through the probe
This build-up creates a higher pressure and will result in an erroneous airspeed reading due to a higher dynamic pressure
This is the compressibility error, and it will induce the ASI to over-read
learning.explanation: Above a certain speed, the air molecules are hitting the pitot probe too fast to normally flow through the probe. This build-up creates a higher pressure and will result in an erroneous airspeed reading due to a higher dynamic pressure. This is the compressibility error, and it will induce the ASI to over-read. For instance, the IAS (or CAS) will be too high than it is in reality, and a correction needs to be applied to account for the compressibility error to obtain the Equivalent Air Speed (EAS). The higher the airspeed, the higher the compressibility error. Besides the airspeed, the compressibility error is also influenced by the altitude. In fact, the less dense air at high altitudes is more easily compressed than at lower levels. The ASI’s calibration formulae include a factor addressing the compressibility of the air so that correct dynamic pressure is measured. Compressibility is becoming significant when the TAS exceeds 300 kt or the IAS is greater than 150 kt.
